Ptolemy XII Auletes succeeds Ptolemy XI Alexander II to the throne of Egypt.
Alexandria comes under Roman jurisdiction.
The Arch of Titus is constructed.
The silver content of the Roman denarius rises to % under emperor Domitian, up from % in the reign of Vitellius.
Possible date of the First Epistle of Peter.
Pliny the Younger is flamen Divi Augusti (priest in the cult of the Emperor).
September – Domitian succeeds his brother Titus as emperor. Domitian is not a soldier like his two predecessors, and his administration is directed towards the reinforcement of a monarchy.
The Second Mithridatic War ends with the status quo.
Sang Hongyang and Confucian scholars debate over the state monopoly of Iron and Salt.
Sulla is appointed dictator, executes his political enemies in a series of proscriptions, and implements aristocratic reforms to the Roman government.
Domitian levies Legio I Minervia.

Gnaeus Julius Agricola raises a fleet, and encircles the Celtic tribes beyond the Forth; the Caledonians rise in great numbers against the Romans. They attack the camp of Legio IX Hispana at night, but Agricola sends his cavalry in, and puts them to flight.
Dio Chrysostom is banished from Rome, Italy, and Bithynia, after advising one of the Emperor's conspiring relatives.
Emperor Domitian becomes Roman Consul.
Algacus unites the Picts (, men) in Scotland, and is made chieftain of the Caledonian Confederacy.
November : Sulla slaughters the Samnite prisoners in the Villa publica; the senate rejects his proscription plan.
Pompey is ordered by Sulla to stamp out Marian rebels in Sicily and Africa, after his campaigns in he gets the insulting nickname of adulescentulus carnifex, the "teenage butcher".
Lucius Licinius Murena launches a raid against Pontus in the Battle of Halys, starting the Second Mithridatic War.

The Aurigid shower parent comet C/1911 N1 returns to the inner solar system and sheds the dust particles that one revolution later cause the 1935, 1986, 1994, and 2007 Aurigid meteor outbursts on Earth.
April: Sulla defeats the consul Gaius Marius the Younger at the Battle of Sacriportus, and takes control of Rome.
Possible date that Demetrius of Tarsus visits an island in the Hebrides populated by holy men, possibly druids.
Emperor Domitian fights the Chatti, a Germanic tribe. His victory allows the construction of fortifications along the Rhine-frontier.
Possible date of the Battle of Mons Graupius : According to Tacitus,, Britons and 360 Romans are killed.
In Rome, the castration of slaves is prohibited.
Domitian is, again, also a Roman Consul.
Gnaeus Pompeius, age, raises, on his own initiative, a private army of three legions from his father's veterans and clientelae in Picenum.

Tigranes the Great, King of Armenia was invited by a faction in the Seleucid civil wars, entered Syria and effectively ended Seleucid rule. Though a weakened Seleucid monarchy was briefly restored after Roman victories, ongoing instability led Pompey to abolish the dynasty and annex Syria as a Roman province in.
Lucius Licinius Murena, the Roman governor of Asia, clashes with the Pontic forces of Mithridates VI, starting the Second Mithridatic War.

Spring – Lucius Cornelius Sulla returns to Italy from his campaigns in Greece and lands with his legions unopposed at Brundisium. He defeats the popular forces of Gaius Norbanus in the Battle of Mount Tifata.
Two new buildings were completed on the Capitoline Hill in Rome: the Temple of Jupitor Optimus Maximus and the Tabularium.
Possible date of the Battle of Mons Graupius, in which Gnaeus Julius Agricola defeats the Caledonians.
Domitian increases the troops' pay by one third, thus securing their loyalty.
The construction of the limes, a line of Roman fortifications from the Rhine to the Danube, has begun.
Hange from Jianchu to Yuanhe era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.
Through his election as consul for ten years and censor for life, Domitian openly subordinates the republican aspect of the state to the monarchical.
Battle of Cana: The Arab Nabataean Kingdom decisively defeats the Greek Seleucid Empire, slaying King Antiochus XII Dionysus, at modern-day Umm Qais in Jordan.
The First Mithridatic War comes to an end.
Baekje invades the outskirts of Silla in the Korean peninsula. The war continues until the peace treaty of.
Domitian appoints himself censor for life, which gives him the right to control the Senate. His totalitarian tendencies put the senatorial aristocracy firmly in opposition to him.
Dacians under Decebalus engage in two wars against the Romans from this year to or.
Emperor Domitian repulses a Dacian invasion of Moesia.
First Mithridatic War: Lucius Cornelius Sulla again defeats Archelaus in the decisive Battle of Orchomenus.
Roman general (and future emperor) Trajan begins a campaign to crush an uprising in Germania.
Emperor Domitian introduces the Capitoline Games.
Ban Gu (Pan Kou) and his sister Ban Zhao (Pan Tchao) compose the History of China.
Germania is divided into two provinces, Germania Inferior and Germania Superior (approximate date).

First Battle of Tapae: Roman legions face disaster in Dacia, when Roman general Cornelius Fuscus launches a powerful offensive that becomes a failure. Encircled in the valley of Timi, he dies along with his entire army.
March – Siege of Athens (– ) ends when Sulla captures Athens from the Pontic army, removing the tyrant Aristion.
Lucius Licinius Lucullus decisively defeats the Mithridatic fleet in the Battle of Tenedos.

First Mithridatic War March – Siege of Athens (– ) ends when Sulla captures Athens from the Pontic army, removing the tyrant Aristion. Lucius Licinius Lucullus decisively defeats the Mithridatic fleet in the Battle of Tenedos.
The Dardani ally with Pontus and are defeated by Sulla soon after.
The Roman forces of Lucius Cornelius Sulla defeat the Pontic forces of Archelaus in the Battle of Chaeronea.
The Roman Julius Maternus explores western Africa (approximate date).
Lyon, a city in Gaul, has a population of over, citizens (approximate date).
Sextus Julius Sparsus gains power in the Roman Senate (approximate date).
Decebalus becomes king of Dacia.
Halley's Comet makes its third confirmed apparition, recorded by Babylonian scribes as being visible in the sky "day beyond day" for about one month.

Gnaeus Octavius and Lucius Cornelius Cinna are inaugurated as consuls. With Cinna seeking to enrol the Italians into all the tribes per vim, he is expelled from the city by Octavius and replaced as consul by Lucius Merula.
March – The eight-year-old Liu Fuling becomes emperor, with Huo Guang General-in-Chief and regent.

First Mithridatic War: Siege of Athens (– ) – Sulla arrives in Greece and from Autumn besieges Athens. He orders Lucius Licinius Lucullus to raise a fleet from Rome's allies around the eastern Mediterranean.

March – Emperor Wu of Han dies after a -year reign in which he leads the Han dynasty through its greatest expansion. The Empire's borders span from modern Kyrgyzstan in the west, to Mongolia in the north, to Korea in the east, and to northern Vietnam in the south.
The First Dacian War ends: Decebalus becomes a client king of Rome, he receives money, craftsmen and war machines to protect the borders of the Roman Empire.

Emperor Han Zhangdi dies at age after a -year reign in which Chinese military forces have become powerful enough to march against tribes who threaten their northern and western borders. Having used intrigue as well as armed might to achieve his ends, Zhangdi and his General Ban Chao have reestablished Chinese influence in Inner Asia, but court eunuchs have increased their power during the emperor's reign.
Two Egyptian obelisks are erected in Benevento in front of the Temple of Isis, in honour of Emperor Domitian.
Pope Clement I succeeds Pope Anacletus I as the fourth pope.
Quintilian retires from teaching and from pleading, to compose his great work on the training of the orator (Institutio Oratoria).

Emperor Wu of Han makes preparations for the six-year-old Liu Fuling to be made Crown Prince and establishes Huo Guang as the future regent. The emperor executes Fuling's mother Lady Gouyi so that she cannot dominate the state while Fuling is a child emperor.
The Dardani, Scordisci, and the Maedi attack the Roman province of Macedonia.

August: The consul Lucius Cornelius Sulla becomes the first Roman commander to march on Rome with his army and to capture the city by force. This extraordinary act is prompted by his desire to maintain his proconsular command for the First Mithridatic War in Asia Minor.
The Social War ends with the defeat of the Italian allies by the Romans.
May – King Mithridates VI of Pontus invades Greece. Defeating the Roman forces four times in succession, he conquers Bithynia, Phrygia, Mysia, Lycia, Pamphylia, Ionia and Cappadocia.
January – Lucius Antonius Saturninus incites a revolt against Emperor Domitian (it is suppressed by January ).
June – Battle of Ikh Bayan: The Han Chinese army under Dou Xian, allied with the southern Xiongnu, is victorious over the Northern Xiongnu.
Legio XIII Gemina is transferred to Dacia, to help in the war against King Decebalus.
Aquincum (old Budapest, Óbuda) is founded (approximate date).
First year of Yongyuan era of the Chinese Han dynasty.
Mithridates VI of Pontus invades Bithynia and Cappadocia, thus beginning the First Mithridatic War.
Icero ends his service in the Roman army.
Lex Pompeia grants Latin rights to cities in Cisalpine Gaul.
The former Han General-in-Chief Li Guangli, now the son-in-law of Hulugu Chanyu, is arrested and sacrificed to the gods to restore the health of Hulugu's mother.
Pompeii is annexed by the Roman Republic.
The Young Flavian Woman is made. It is now kept at Musei Capitolini, Rome (approximate date).

Li Guangli and his in-law Prime Minister Liu Qumao seek to recommend Liu Bo, Li Guangli's nephew, as the new Crown Prince, and while Li Guangli is on campaign, Liu Qumao and his wife are executed and Li Guangli's wife imprisoned, having been charged with cursing the emperor and seeking to replace him with Liu Bo.
The Lex Iulia grants citizenship to all Italians who did not oppose Rome during the Social War.
The Etruscans are granted Roman citizenship.

Wishing to please the emperor, Li Guangli and his, men penetrate as far as the Selenga River. A detachment crosses the river and defeats an army of, under the Xiongnu Left General-in-Chief, who is killed.
The Xiongnu invade the Prefectures of Wuyuan and Jiuquan and kill the commandants of both Prefectures.
Ban Chao is made protector-general of the Western Regions.
Pliny the Younger is named a tribunus plebis.
Rome is described by Statius in his poems.
Manius Acilius Glabrio and Marcus Ulpius Traianus become Roman Consuls.
Following further accusations of witchcraft, the emperor executes hundreds of imperial officials and concubines.

Emperor Wu of Han executes Prime Minister Gongsun He (the brother-in-law of Empress Wei Zifu) and his clan because Gongsun's son is accused of adultery with the emperor's daughter Princess Yangshi and witchcraft.
September - The Xiongnu invade the prefectures of Shanggu and Wuyuan.
Onsuls: Sextus Julius Caesar and Lucius Marcius Philippus.
After being defeated in Chang'an, Liu Ju and his mother, Empress Wei Zifu, commit suicide. Emperor Wu exterminates the followers of Liu Ju and their families.
The Flavian Palace is completed on the Palatine.
Emperor Domitian becomes a Roman Consul.

In spring, several tribes (probably Marcomanni, Quadi, Jazyges) cross the Danube and attack Pannonia, probably destroying Legio XXI Rapax. These tribes are defeated from May to December, and chased back over the river.
The Roman army moves into Mesopotamia (modern Syria).
Sulla repulses Tigranes of Armenia from Cappadocia.

Levant earthquake, earthquake mentioned in catalogues of historical earthquakes. An earthquake and a tsunami reportedly affected areas of the Levant, including the modern states of Cyprus, Egypt, Israel, and Syria.
Gaius Sentius becomes Roman governor of Macedonia. He serves until.
Onsuls: Gaius Claudius Pulcher and Marcus Perperna.
In the first diplomatic contact between Rome and Parthia, Sulla meets with a Parthian envoy, resulting in the parties recognizing the Euphrates as a common frontier.
Josephus completes his Jewish Antiquities (or in ).
Emperor Domitian persecutes the Christians.
The Xianbei incorporates, Xiongnu, and establishes the Xianbei State in Mongolia (approximate date).
Pliny the Younger is named a praetor.
End of era Taishi of Emperor Wu of Han China.
Roman consuls: Gaius Valerius Flaccus and Marcus Herennius.
The Chinese General Ban Chao completes his conquest of the Tarim Basin by taking Yānqi, which is located on the strategic Silk Road.
Emperor Domitian rebuilds and rededicates the Curia Julia (meeting place of the Roman Senate), which had burned down in.
Domitian banishes all Stoic philosophers from Rome.
The Roman poet Publius Papinius Statius retires to Naples from Rome (approximate date).
Lucius Cornelius Sulla is elected praetor urbanus.
Onsuls: Gaius Coelius Caldus and Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus.
Approximate date – Nicomedes IV succeeds his father Nicomedes III as king of Bithynia.
The Shakas start to control northwest India.
The first attempt to open a Latin rhetorical school.
Domitian executes senators out of paranoiac fears that they are plotting to kill him.
Possible date for the writing of the First Epistle of Peter.
Emperor Domitian and Titus Flavius Clemens become Roman Consuls.
The Roman consul Manius Acilius Glabrio is ordered by Domitian to descend into the arena of the Colosseum to fight a lion. After he kills the animal, Domitian banishes and puts him to death.
The Book of Revelation is written (approximate date).
Onsuls: Lucius Licinius Crassus and Quintus Mucius Scaevola Pontifex.
Tigranes the Great becomes king of Armenia.
Philip I Philadelphus and Antiochus XI Ephiphanes succeeded as co-rulers after the deposition of Seleucus VI Epiphanes.
"Forty-metre structure" at Emain Macha (near modern Armagh, Northern Ireland) was built and destroyed, presumably for ritual or ceremonial purposes.
Ariobarzanes I Philoromaios becomes king of Cappadocia with Roman backing.
September – Emperor Domitian is stabbed to death by a freedman at the age after a -year reign, in a palace conspiracy involving officers of the Praetorian Guard. The Flavian Dynasty ends.
Marcus Ulpius Traianus becomes governor of Upper Germany.
Nerva is declared emperor by the Roman Senate as the new ruler of the Roman Empire. He recalls citizens exiled by Domitian; this is the beginning of the Era of the Five Good Emperors.
The Arch of Titus is completed in Rome.
The Book of Revelation is written (approximate date).
Start of the Taishi era in the Han dynasty.
Onsuls: Gaius Cassius Longinus and Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus.
Seleucus VI Epiphanes becomes king of the Seleucid Empire following the death of his father Antiochus VIII Grypus, and defeating in battle Antiochus IX Cyzicenus.
Yrene is left to the people of the Roman Republic by its ruler Ptolemy Apion.
Gloucester, England is founded as Colonia Glevum Nervensis by the Romans.
The Roman colony of Cuicul is started in Numidia.
October – Emperor Nerva recalls his general Marcus Ulpius Trajanus, age, from the German frontier and is forced by the Praetorian Guard to adopt him as his successor.
Gan Ying, is sent as an emissary to Daquin, though he is turned back by the Parthians.
Sextus Julius Frontinus is appointed superintendent of the aqueducts (curator aquarum) in Rome. At least aqueducts supply the city with 250 million US gallons (950, m) of water per day.
A decree of the Roman Senate bans human sacrifices.
L. Domitius takes harsh measures to restore order in Sicily.
Onsuls: Gnaeus Cornelius Lentulus and Publius Licinius Crassus.
Decianus, the prosecutor of Furius, is himself condemned for his remarks about the death of Saturninus.
Ariarathes VIII is forced out of Cappadocia by Mithridates, and dies soon afterwards.
Tacitus finishes his Germania (approximate date).
January – Nerva dies of a fever at his villa in the Gardens of Sallust and is succeeded by his adopted son Trajan. Trajan is the first Roman Emperor born in Italica, near Seville.
Trajan elevates Ladenburg to city status.
January – Emperor Nerva suffers a stroke during a private audience.
The silver content of the Roman denarius rises to percent under emperor Trajan, up from percent under Domitian.
The Senate passes the Lex Caecilia Didia, which bans omnibus bills.

Emperor Wu of Han sends the Han general Gongsun Ao on a mission to rescue general Li Ling from Xiongnu captivity. Gongsun achieves little but receives incorrect information that Li has been training Xiongnu soldiers.
Onsuls: Quintus Caecilius Metellus Nepos and Titus Didius.
Emperor Trajan returns to Rome.
November – Pope Evaristus succeeds Pope Clement I as the fifth pope according to Roman Catholic tradition.
Emissaries of the Kushan Empire reach the Roman Empire.
August – Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 581, recording the sale of a slave girl, is written.
The Han generals Lu Bode and Gongsun Ao march into the Zhuoxie Mountains, but they encounter no Xiongnu forces and turn back.

Autumn – The Han general Li Ling leads 5000 crack infantry and a cavalry force from Juyan Lake into the eastern Altay Mountains but is pursued by Qiedihou Chanyu. After a desperate fighting retreat across more than 500km of Xiongnu territory, the Han expedition runs out of arrows.
Emperor Wu of Han has the 'Grand Historian' Sima Qian castrated after the latter argues in defense of Li Ling's surrender.

The Han general Li Guangli marches west from Jiuquan with, cavalrymen to attack the Tuqi King of the Right in the Tian Shan Mountains. After an initial victory, the Han are surrounded, and they lose more than, men while breaking out of the encirclement.
Onsuls: Aulus Postumius Albinus and Marcus Antonius.
The compilation of the Kama Sutra begins in India.
Pacores (last king of the Indo-Parthian kingdom) takes the throne.
The Temple of the God of Medicine is built in Anguo, China.
The future emperor, Hadrian, marries Vibia Sabina.
Bricks become the primary building material in the Roman Empire.
Han-Xiongnu War: the Han general Zhao Ponu escapes Xiongnu custody and returns to China.
Manius Aquillius celebrates an ovation for victories in the Second Servile War.

Late summer–autumn: Saturninus stands for tribune again for the following year, and is elected. His associate, the praetor Gaius Servilius Glaucia, attempts to stand for the consulship (illegally, as praetors cannot immediately become consul).

War of the Heavenly Horses: the Han expedition under Li Guangli returns victorious to China. He is followed by dynastic representatives sent by various Central Asian kings, so that they may pay tribute to Emperor Wu of Han.
Tigranes II of Armenia is placed on the Armenian throne by the Parthians in exchange for the cession of "seventy valley" (approximate date).
Emperor Trajan starts an expedition against Dacia, exceeding the limits of the Roman Empire set by Augustus.
Trajan begins his fourth consulship.
Epictetus writes and publishes The Discourses of Epictetus (approximate date).
Third Battle of Tapae: Roman forces, led by Trajan, defeat the Dacian king Decebalus in Transylvania.

War of the Heavenly Horses: Han general Li Guangli detaches forces to attack Yucheng. After a failed attack by Wang Shengshen and Hu Chongguo, in which Wang is killed, a new Han detachment under Shangguan Jie defeats and captures the king of Yucheng.

Han-Xiongnu War: At the beginning of the year, Xulihu Chanyu dies from illness and is succeeded by Qiedihou Chanyu. Qiedihou releases the Han envoys detained by the Xiongnu and receives gifts from Emperor Wu of Han.
Ptolemy Apion inherits the kingdom of Cyrenaica.
July – Battle of Vercellae (Battle of the Raudine Plain or Battle of Campi Raudii): The Roman consuls Gaius Marius and Manius Aquillius defeat the Cimbri.
Lucius Julius Ursus Servianus and Lucius Licinius Sura become Roman consuls.
The port of Portus is enlarged.
Emperor Trajan returns to Rome after a successful campaign against Dacia, through which he reestablishes clear Roman sovereignty over King Decebalus.
Planning and surveying for the port of Ostia is undertaken.
Having organised the territories of the Tarim Basin, Chinese General Ban Chao retires to Luoyang and dies shortly thereafter.

War of the Heavenly Horses: the Han expeditionary force under Li Guangli conquers the state of Luntai. Li Guangli then besieges Alexandria Eschate, the capital of Dayuan in the Hellenistic Ferghana Valley, despite having lost half his army to hunger, thirst and battle by the time he reached the city.
The Cimbri defeat the Consul Quintus Lutatius Catulus in the Adige Valley.
Er Chanyu marches against Shouxiang but dies en route from illness and is succeeded by his uncle Xulihu.
Gaius Marius defeats the Sciri and Teutones at Aix-en-Provence (or Battle of Aquae Sextae).
Marcus Marius was likely elected praetor for.
In Palmyra, Syria, a Temple of the Sun is erected to the god Baal.
Pliny the Younger becomes a member of the college of Augurs (–).
Emperor Trajan and Manius Laberius Maximus become Roman consuls.
Legio X Gemina moves to Vienna, where it remains until the.
Tryphon and Athenion lead the Second Servile War in Sicily.
Emperor Wu of Han reinforces Li Guangli's army with,000 men, numerous horses and beasts of burden, and more than fifty high-ranking officers. Li Guangli's army then returns west.

After having fought their way west across arid regions, the Han expeditionary force under Li Guangli fails to capture the Dayuan city of Yucheng and returns east to the area of Dunhuang, having lost % of their men.
Gaius Marius prepares a campaign against the Ambrones and Teutones (under king Teutobod) who are settled in Gaul.
Summer – The Han army retreats south, but the Xiongnu surround them. After capturing Zhao Ponu during the night, the Xiongnu defeat and force the surrender of the Han soldiers.

Apollodorus of Damascus builds a stone bridge over the Danube more than 1,000 meters (3,300 feet) long, almost meters high and meters wide. The bridge connects what is now Serbia with Romania (at the time known as Dacia).
In India, figures of Buddha replace abstract motifs on decorative items.
Trajan gives the order to have the Alcántara Bridge, constructed by the architect Lacer, built over the Tagus River at Alcántara.
Nijmegen is renamed Ulpia Noviomagus Batavorum.
Pliny the Younger continues as a member of the College of Augurs (–).
Aristobulus I succeeds John Hyrcanus, becoming king and high priest of Judea, until.
Second Servile War: Athenion starts a slave rebellion in Segesta.
Rome enacts a state of emergency, as the way to Italy lays open to the Germanic invaders. Gaius Marius, the conqueror of Jugurtha, is elected consul for the second time.

War of the Heavenly Horses: Emperor Wu of Han sends an army of 6000 cavalrymen and,000 convicts under Li Guangli to attack Dayuan in modern Kyrgyzstan after Wugua, the king of Dayuan, refuses to send the Han any of the prized horses of Dayuan and, following a contentious meeting with the Han diplomats, has a vassal king kill the diplomats and seize their goods. The Han expeditionary force proceeds with difficulty, marching through arid regions and facing hostile cities.

Pacorus II of Parthia dies after a -year reign, in which he has reclaimed all of his empire. His successor Vologases III reigns until, suppressing brief rebellions, as he battles against the Kushan and Alani.
Emperor Trajan starts the second expedition against Dacia; he leaves with the Imperial Roman fleet from Brundusium.
The Romans conquer Kerak from the Nabateans.
Pope Alexander I succeeds Pope Evaristus as the sixth pope according to Roman Catholic tradition (approximate date).
Permanent castrum of Legio II Adiutrix at Aquincum (modern Budapest) in Pannonia.

Wuwei Chanyu of the Xiongnu dies and is succeeded by his youthful son Er Chanyu. That winter heavy snowstorms lead to the deaths of many livestock, and there is discontent with the new ruler, who is regarded as belligerent.
Lucius Cornelius Sulla secures the capture of Jugurtha. His success is made possible by the treachery of Bocchus I, king of Mauretania, and this ends the Jugurthine War (which began in ).
The Han dynasty forms an alliance with the Wusun by marrying a Han princess to their king.
Gaius Marius, together with the consul Publius Rutilius Rufus, initiates sweeping reforms of the Roman army.
January 1 – Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus become Roman consuls.
February – Emperor He of Han dies after a -year reign. Empress Dowager Deng places her infant son Han Shangdi on the Chinese throne.
Romans construct a road between Eilat and Damascus.
Aelianus Tacticus (or Aelian) writes his Taktike Theoria (approximate date).
September – Han Shangdi dies after a -month reign and is succeeded by his young cousin Han Andi as ruler of the Chinese Eastern Han dynasty.
Battle of Sarmizegetusa: The Dacians are defeated with,000 captured. King Decebalus flees and commits suicide.
Following the death of General-in-Chief Wei Qing, his sister Empress Wei Zifu and nephew Crown Prince Liu Ju begin to lose influence at court.
The Romans under Quintus Servilius Caepio seize the Gold of Tolosa while recapturing the Volcae town.
Nicomedes III of Bithynia and Mithridates VI of Pontus share their dominion over Paphlagonia.
Lucius Licinius Sura and Quintus Sosius Senecio become consuls of Rome.
Han Andi (An-ti) becomes emperor of China.
First year of the yongchu era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.
An Indian ambassador is received by Emperor Trajan.

Gaius Marius, to whom the putative Marian reforms of the Roman army are commonly attributed, arrives in North Africa to lead the war against Jugurtha, with a young quaestor named Lucius Cornelius Sulla as a subordinate.
The uprising of Saumachus against Mithridates VI in the Bosporan Kingdom.

In the course of the migration of the Cimbrians and Teutons, a Germanic-Celtic confederation including the Helvetic tribes of the Tigurinians and Tougenians, under the leadership of Divico, ambush and defeat the Roman legions under Lucius Cassius Longinus, Lucius Caesoninus and Gaius Popillius Laenas at the Battle of Burdigala on the Garonne. As a result, the town of Tolosa, populated by the Volcae, revolts against the Roman Empire.
Tacitus writes Histories, which covers the period from to.
Appius Annius Trebonius Gallus and Marcus Atilius Bradua become Roman Consuls.
The Hypogeum of Yarhai, an underground tomb from the Syrian city of Palmyra dedicated to the family of Yarhai, is built.

Emperor Wu of Han founds Jiuquan in the Hexi Corridor as a military outpost on the Silk Road to Central Asia. It serves to protect diplomats and merchants, and it cuts off the kings of the region from the Xiongnu.
Roman forces under Quintus Caecilius Metellus Numidicus defeat the forces of Jugurtha of Numidia at the Battle of the Muthul, with Gaius Marius as a subordinate.
Han subjugates Gojoseon and divides it into four prefectures. Xun Zhi is executed for infighting.
Summer – After being deserted by some of his officials, king Ugeo of Gojoseon is assassinated. Cheng Yi takes over the defense of Wangxian but is killed by Han sympathizers.
The Han generals Yang Pu and Xun Zhi besiege Wangxian, the capital of Gojoseon. Infighting between the generals leads Xun Zhi to arrest Yang Pu.
June – The Aqua Traiana is inaugurated by Emperor Trajan; the aqueduct channels water from Lake Bracciano, kilometers northwest of Rome.
Pliny the Younger is legate to Bithynia.
Osroes I of Parthia succeeds his brother Pacorus II, and rules over the western Parthian Empire.
The Via Traiana is constructed at the Emperor Trajan's personal expense; the road connects Benevento with Brundisium.
The Baths of Trajan, built by the architect Apollodorus of Damascus, are dedicated during the Calends. The thermae are constructed on the platform of the Palace of Nero (Domus Aurea) in Rome.
Han campaigns against Dian: Emperor Wu launches a new campaign against the Dian Kingdom and establishes the Yizhou commandery in Yunnan during the dynasty's expansion southward.
Emperor Wu of Han inspects the Han Empire, traveling,000 km (5,600 mi). He also sends diplomats to search for the legendary Penglai Island.
The Han general Zhao Ponu and 700 cavalrymen are victorious in the Battle of Loulan in the Tarim Basin, capturing the king of Loulan in the first Han intervention west of the Hexi Corridor.
A Roman army under Marcus Junius Silanus is defeated by the Cimbri and Teutones near the river Rhône.
Autumn – Emperor Wu orders the invasion. The Han general Yang Pu crosses the Yellow Sea and marches on the capital Wangxian but is defeated outside its gates.

Aravans make regular departures from Luoyang with Chinese ginger, cassia (a type of cinnamon), and silk to be bartered in Central Asia for gold, silver, glassware, pottery, cloth, and intaglio gems from Rome.
The Forum of Trajan is constructed in Rome, by the Syrian architect Apollodorus of Damascus.
The Roman Empire has more than,000 kilometers (,000 mi) of roads.
Suetonius, Roman historian, publishes Viris Illustribus ("On Famous Men" – in the field of literature).
Emperor Wu of Han annexes Dongyue and Minyue and relocates their population to the area between the Yangtze and Huai rivers.
Jugurtha, king of Numidia, defeats a Roman army under Aulus Postumius Albinus.
In winter, the Han general Yang Pu retakes Wulin, and a faction of Dongyue nobles kill their king Zou Yushan before surrendering to the Han general Han Yue.
Emperor Trajan sends Pliny the Younger to be governor (legatus Augusti) of Bithynia.
Emperor Wu of Han sends two maritime fleets and three armies, including an army under Yang Pu, to invade Dongyue.
In winter, the Han general Yang Pu captures Xunxia Gorge and Shimen and defeats the Nanyue army. He and Han general Lu Bode then attack the Nanyue capital Panyu and receive its surrender.
Han-Xiongnu War: the Han generals Gongsun He and Zhao Ponu invade deep into Xiongnu territory, Gongsun marching from Wuhuan and Zhao from Lingju. However, neither come upon a Xiongnu army.
Nanyue's ally Cangwu submits to the Han dynasty, and Nanyue is divided into nine prefectures. The Han dynasty thereby extends its control to modern-day North Vietnam.
The city of Rome is devastated by fire.
Emperor Trajan and Titus Sextius Cornelius Africanus become Roman consuls.
King Jima succeeds Pasa as ruler of the Korean kingdom of Silla.
Hadrian succeeds Gaius Julius Cassius Steirieus as archon of Athens.
August – Salonia Matidia receives the title of Augusta upon the death of Marciana.
Tacitus is named proconsul of the Roman province of Asia (–).
Emperor Wu executes his favourite necromancer Luan Da for fraud.

The king of Dongyue, Zou Yushan, sends an army to link up with Yang Pu, but he secretly sends an envoy to Zhao Jiande and halts the transport fleet to await the war's outcome, claiming that the weather is preventing its advance.
The Roman Senate declares war against Jugurtha following the Siege of Cirta.

Lü Jia, Premier of the Han vassal state of Nanyue, opposes increased Han control and refuses to appear before the king of Nanyue and the envoys of Han. He rebels against the Han when Emperor Wu sends an armed force of 2,000 men to kill him and his allies.
Autumn – Emperor Wu launches a major invasion of Nanyue, sending five riverine fleets to invade under Lu Bode, Yang Pu and three former Yue generals.
Emperor Trajan sails from Rome to begin his expedition against Parthia. He arrives in Athens where Parthian envoys greet him with olive branches, a sign of peace.
Trajan's Column near the Colosseum in Rome is completed to commemorate the Emperor's victory over the Dacians in the Second Dacian War.
"Pattini dheivam" worship is inaugurated in Kannagi Temple in the Chera Kingdom in India, by Emperor Cenkuttuvan; the function is attended by GajaBahu, king of Central Sri Lanka.
Osroes I of Parthia violates the treaty with Rome by installing a puppet ruler in Armenia. Emperor Trajan marches east, without first attempting to use diplomacy to resolve the disagreement.
Last year of Yongchu era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.
Antiochus IX Cyzicenus becomes king of the Seleucid Empire.
Eltiberians lead a war against the Romans.
An incense burner, later found in the tomb of Liu Sheng, Prince of Zhongshan in Mancheng, Hebei, is made during the Han dynasty. It is now kept at Hebei Provincial Museum, Shijiazhuang.
The state of Nanyue, a vassal of the Han dynasty, agrees to submit to Han laws and receives envoys to oversee the succession of the young king Zhao Xing.

Battle of Noreia: The Cimbri and Teutones cross the Danube and enter the lands of the Celtic tribe, the Taurisci (centered in what is now Austria and north-eastern Italy). The latter sent emissaries to Rome, seeking help in dealing with the migration.
Hange of Patriarch of Constantinople from Patriarch Sedecion to Patriarch Diogenes.
A monument to Philopappos, prince-in-exile of old Commagene (a buffer-state between Rome and Parthia) is erected in Athens.
Emperor Trajan defeats the Parthians and overruns Armenia and northern Mesopotamia.
Onstruction begins on the Arch of Trajan in Benevento.
The kingdom of Osroene becomes a vassal kingdom of the Roman Empire.
An earthquake destroys Apamea and Antioch in Syria. The local bishop is held responsible (he will be martyred and remembered as St. Ignatius).
Emperor Trajan is cut off in southern Mesopotamia after his invasion of that region.
Alexandria in Egypt is damaged during the Jewish-Greek civil wars. Marcus Rutilius Lupus, the Roman governor, sends Legio XXII Deiotariana to protect the inhabitants of Memphis.
Trajan captures the Parthian capital of Ctesiphon.
Pope Sixtus I succeeds Alexander I as the seventh pope of Rome (according to Catholic biographies).
Gaius Marius is praetor in Rome: he defeats Celtic tribes in modern-day Spain.
Parthia makes a trade treaty with China.
The Kingdom of Sheba collapses.
Marcus Aemilius Scaurus defeats the Carni Celtic tribes of Northern Italy, leading to their submission to Roman rule.
Trajan removes Osroes I as king of Parthia, and appoints his son Parthamaspates in his place. Parthamaspates romanizes his name to Parthicus.

In summer, rebellious movement emerges in Mesopotamia against Roman occupation. General Lusius Quietus is sent by Trajan to suppress the uprisings, recovering Nisibis, besieging and sacking Edessa, and waging war against local Jews.
Trajan sends laureatae to the Roman Senate on account of his victories and being conqueror of Parthia.
Quintus Marcius Turbo sails to Alexandria and defeats Jewish insurgents in several pitched battles.
Emperor Trajan completes his invasion of Parthia by capturing the cities of Seleucia, Babylon, Ctesiphon and Susa, marking the high-water mark of the Roman Empire's eastern expansion.
Ptolemy IX Philometor Soter II Lathyros becomes king of Egypt and claims the throne.

June – At the death of Ptolemy VIII Physcon, Cleopatra III has chosen her younger son Ptolemy X Alexander as co-regent, but the Alexandrians force her to bring Ptolemy IX from Cyprus, of which he is governor.
August 9 - 11 – Emperor Trajan dies of a stroke at Selinus in Cilicia, age, while en route from Mesopotamia to Italy, leaving the Roman Empire at its maximal territorial extent.

Hadrian, who will reign until, succeeds him. Hadrian, a Spaniard like Trajan, as Emperor inaugurates a policy of retrenchment and cultural integration, giving up the policy of conquest of his predecessor in order to consolidate the empire.
Hadrian returns large parts of Mesopotamia to the Parthians, as part of a peace settlement.
The Roman Empire reaches its greatest extent.
Trajan falls seriously ill, leaving Hadrian in command of the east. On his death bed, Trajan allegedly adopts Hadrian and designates him as his successor.
The oldest known painted depiction of a wheelbarrow is found in a Chinese tomb of Chengde, Sichuan province, dated to this year.
Emperor Hadrian is also a Roman Consul.
Pantheon, in Rome, starts to be built (approximate date).
– – Battle of Centaurs and Wild Beasts, from Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is made (approximate date). It may be a copy of a painting done by the late Greek artist Zeuxis.
The north-south feud between the Hun Dynasty ends.
The Roman colony of Narbo Martius is founded in Gallia Transalpina.
Micipsa dies and Numidia, following the king's wish, is divided into three parts, a third each ruled by Micipsa's own sons, Adherbal and Hiempsal I, and the king's adopted son, Jugurtha.
The Second Dalmatian War ends with victory for Rome. Lucius Caecilius Metellus assumes the surname Delmaticus.
Emperor Wu of Han secretly executes his favourite necromancer Shao Weng for fraud.
Hadrian also visits Britain in this year at the request of governor of Britain Quintus Pompeius Falco.
Salonia Matidia (a niece of former Emperor Trajan) dies. Hadrian delivers her funeral oration, and grants her a temple in Rome.

Emperor Hadrian stations Legio VI Victrix in Roman Britain, to assist in quelling the resistance of a local rebellion. The legion is key in securing the victory, and eventually replaces Legio IX Hispana at Eboracum.
Reign in Northern India by Nahapana, Scythian king. He attacks the kingdom of Andhra and annexes Southern Rajputana.
Government monopolies are established in iron, salt and liquor.
Emperor Wu suspends further campaigning against the Xiongnu due to a shortage of horses.
Spring: Han Chinese forces under the General-in-Chief Wei Qing and the cavalry general Huo Qubing invade the Xiongnu Empire.
Huo Qubing crosses the eastern Gobi, defeats and executes Bijuqi, defeats the Tuqi (Worthy Prince) of the Left, and captures three kings. He reaches as far as Lake Baikal.
The second Dalmatian war begins.
Hange of era name from Yuanchu (7th year) to Yongning of the Chinese Eastern Han dynasty.
A Kushan ambassadorial contingent visits with Hadrian.
The Scythians dominate western India: Punjab, Sind, the north of Gujarat and a portion of central India.
Legio IX Hispana last known to be in existence.

Approximate date Legio IX Hispana last known to be in existence. The Market Gate of Miletus is built at Miletos (moved in modern times to Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Antikensammlung).
Mithridates VI Eupator becomes king of Pontus.
Retaliating against the Han conquest of the Hexi Corridor in the previous year, the Xiongnu invade the provinces of Youbeiping and Dingxiang, killing or capturing over 1000 inhabitants.
The Teutons and the Cimbri migrate south and west to the Danube valley where they encounter the expanding Roman Republic (approximate date).
Roman settlement in present-day Wiesbaden, Germany, is first mentioned.
Emperor Hadrian fixes the border between Roman Britain and Caledonia, on a line running from the River Tyne to the Solway Firth.
Era name changes from Yongning (2nd year) to Jianguang in the Chinese Eastern Han dynasty.
Onstruction of the Temple of Venus and Roma begins in Rome.
Onsul Quintus Fabius Maximus, allied with the Aedui, defeats the Arverni and Allobroges in Transalpine Gaul, thus establishing the province for Rome.

Spring - The Han general Huo Qubing attacks the Supu, vassals of the Xiongnu, and kills their king. He then invades the Hexi Corridor, where he fights a six-day running battle against a son of Yizhixie Chanyu.
A tribunal is established in Rome that executes 3,000 followers of Gracchus.
Summer - Huo Qubing again invades the Hexi Corridor. In an engagement in the Qilian Mountains, he captures the king of the Qiutu.

Kingdom of the Phrygians after founding the city of Mydas in the current Cartagena in Colombia, enter deeper into the current region of Villavicenzo, in the state of Meta and created the city of Acmonia.
Hadrian gives up the territories conquered in Scotland.
Hange of era name from Jianguang (2nd year) to Yanguang of the Chinese Eastern Han dynasty.
September 13 – The building of Hadrian's Wall begins.

Emperor Hadrian orders that a -mile (-kilometer) wall be built to mark the northern Roman Empire while personally visiting the area. Hadrian's Wall, as it comes to be known, is intended to keep the Caledonians, Picts and other tribes at bay.
Vindolanda, a Roman auxiliary fort in northern England, is garrisoned by cohort VIII Batavorum.
Marcus Fulvius Flaccus and Gaius Gracchus become tribunes and propose a number of radical reforms in Rome.
Emperor Wu of Han appoints Liu Ju, his son by Empress Wei Zifu, as Crown Prince.
Gracchus passes a law requiring the state to provide weapons and equipment for the soldiers in the Roman army.
Emperor Hadrian averts a war with Parthia by a personal meeting with Osroes I (according to the Historia Augusta, disputed).
Hadrian's Villa at Tivoli is built.
In China, Ban Yong, son of Ban Chao, reestablishes the Chinese control over the Tarim Basin.
The Temple of Al-Lat in Palmyra is dedicated somewhere between this year and.
Hadrian leads a punitive campaign against Berbers who had been raiding Roman towns in Roman Mauretania.
Spring: The Han General-in-Chief Wei Qing launches two invasions of Xiongnu territory from Dingxiang, defeating two Xiongnu armies and killing or capturing several thousand of the enemy.

Quintus Caecilius Metellus conquers the Balearic Islands for Rome, for which he earns the agnomen "Balearicus." He settles 3,000 Roman and Iberian colonists on the islands and founds the cities of Palma and Pollentia.
Aix-en-Provence founded under the name of Aquae Sextiae by the Roman consul Sextius Calvinus.

For these two campaigns, Emperor Wu of Han orders Wei Qing to make his eighteen-year-old nephew Huo Qubing the commander of a force of 800 cavalry. Raiding deep into enemy territory, Huo's force kills or captures a Xiongnu Prime Minister and a Household Administrator, kills the Marquis of Jiruo (an elder relative of Yizhixie Chanyu), and captures the Chanyu's uncle Luogubi.

Gaius Gracchus elected Roman tribune for the first time. He waits until after his re-election the following year before pushing forward the various civil and agrarian reforms that his brother championed in.
Emperor Hadrian begins to rebuild the Olympeion in Athens.

May – Aulus Larcius Macedo, the former Governor of Galatia; and Publius Ducenius Verres take office for four month as the suffect consuls to succeed Bellicius and Glabrio, and serve until the end of August.
Antinous becomes Hadrian's beloved companion on his journeys through the Roman Empire.
September – Gaius Valerius Severus and Gaius Julius Gallus replace consuls Larcius and Ducenius and serve until the end of the year.
During a voyage to Greece, Hadrian is initiated in the ancient rites known as the Eleusinian Mysteries.
Leopatra II of Egypt and her brother Ptolemy VIII of Egypt reconcile.
Autumn: The Xiongnu retaliate by invading the Prefecture of Dai, where they kill its chief commandant, Zhu Ying.

Spring: The Han general Wei Qing, with an army of,000 cavalry, proceeds from Gaoque into Xiongnu territory, and in a night attack surrounds the Tuqi King of the Right in his camp. The Tuqi escapes, but numerous petty chiefs are captured in this and a second engagement.
Li Xi and Zhang Cigong invade Xiongnu territory from Youbeiping Prefecture but encounter no enemy forces.
Mithridates II succeeds Artabanus I as King of Parthia.

Plague sweeps North Africa in the wake of a locust invasion that destroys large areas of cropland. The plague kills as many as 500,000 in Numidia and possibly,000 on the coast before moving to Italy, where it takes so many lives that villages and towns are abandoned. (or was it around ).
Zhang Heng of Han dynasty China invents a hydraulic-powered armillary sphere.
Hange of emperor of the Chinese Han dynasty from Han Andi to Marquis of Beixiang, then to Han Shundi.
The Satires of Juvenal intimate that bread and circuses (panem et circenses) keep the Roman people happy.
Gautamiputra Satakarni, a king of the Andhra dynasty, conquers the Konkan near Bombay. He then controls central India from coast to coast.
The Xiongnu Tuqi (Worthy Prince) of the Right, especially angry at the loss of the Ordos Plateau, invades the region and kills or carries off a large number of officials and other inhabitants.
In retaliation for the Han conquest of the Ordos Plateau two years prior, three Xiongnu forces raid the Prefectures of Dai, Dingxiang and Shang.

In Rome, Marcus Fulvius Flaccus proposes the extension of Roman citizenship to the northern Italians, but the Senate reacts by sending him off to deal with disturbances around Massilia. And in so doing, commences the conquest of Transalpine Gaul.
Leopatra Thea succeeds to the rule of the Seleucid Empire on the death of Seleucus V. She appoints Antiochus VIII Grypus as co-ruler.
Ompletion of Aqua Tepula aqueduct in Rome.
The old Pantheon is demolished by Emperor Hadrian, and the construction of a new one begins (its date is uncertain, because Hadrian chooses not to inscribe the temple).
First year of the Yongjian era of the Chinese Han dynasty.

Winter /6: The Xiongnu ruler Junchen Chanyu dies, and his younger brother Yizhixie, the Luli King of the Left, overthrows Junchen's son Yudan and sets himself up as the new Chanyu. Yudan flees to the Han and dies a few months later.
Autumn: The Xiongnu cross into Yanmen and kill or capture over 1000 of the inhabitants.

To avoid the Xiongnu and Qiang of the north-west and west respectively, Emperor Wu begins a policy of exploring a possible route of contact with Daxia via India, sending envoys to establish diplomatic relations with and movement through the Dian Kingdom. Wu wishes to receive the submission of Daxia and other states in western Eurasia.
Tyre successfully revolts from the Seleucid Empire.
Seleucus V Philometor succeeds his father Demetrius II as king of the Seleucid Empire. Due to his youth, his stepmother Cleopatra Thea acts as regent.
Hadrian, acting on the advice of his proconsul of Asia, Gaius Minicius Fundanus, determines that Christians shall not be put to death without a trial.
The philosopher Carpocrates rejects ownership of private property as being un-Christian.
Kanishka I starts to rule in the Kushan Empire (approximate date).
Emperor Hadrian returns to Rome, after a seven-year voyage to the Roman provinces.
The Scythians defeat the Parthians in a battle around Media.
The Han rationalize the northern frontier, abandoning the remote region of Zaoyang to the Xiongnu.
January: Emperor Wu of Han begins a policy of pressuring the client kings of the Han dynasty into dividing their kingdoms. Previously, only the eldest son would inherit a kingdom.

Wei Qing defeats a Xiongnu army near Gaoque. He then invades the Ordos Plateau, defeats the Xiongnu and their Baiyang and Loufan allies in the battles of Puni and Fuli, and then defeats the main Xiongnu force.
The Pantheon in Rome is finished.
Emperor Hadrian visits the Roman province of North Africa, in order to inspect Legio III Augusta stationed at Lambaesis. For strategic reasons, the legionnaires are located in the Aurès Mountains.
Roman agriculture declines, as imports from Egypt and North Africa depress wheat prices, making it unprofitable to farm, and forcing many farmers off the land.
King Gaeru of Baekje succeeds to the throne of Baekje in the Korean peninsula.
Hadrian's Wall is completed in Britain. Built mostly of stone in the east and with a wooden palisade in the west.

In response to Han incursions, in or the Xiongnu invade northern China. They kill the governor of Liaoxi, defeat the governor of Yuyang, capture 2000 of the inhabitants of Liaoxi and Yuyang and defeat the Han general Han Anguo.

Having spent a year in Greater Yuezhi, the Han diplomat Zhang Qian begins his return journey to China, having failed to persuade Yuezhi's king to form an alliance against the Xiongnu. Passing by the Pamir, Kunlun, Altun and Qilian Mountains, he and his retinue are then captured by the Xiongnu and taken into custody.
The Han general Wei Qing, with an army of,000 cavalrymen, defeats a Xiongnu army north of Yanmen. The Han general Li Xi attacks the Xiongnu further to the east, riding out of Dai Prefecture.
The Greco-Bactrian kingdom is overrun by the Tokhari.
Artabanus I becomes king of Parthia (approximate date).
Emperor Hadrian continues his voyages, now inspecting Caria, Cappadocia and Syria.
The song "Angel's Hymn" is made.
A defense for Numidia is constructed at Lambaesis by Legio III Augusta.
Hange of Patriarch of Constantinople, from Patriarch Diogenes to Eleutherius.
Total solar eclipse, used by Hipparchus to estimate distance to the Moon.
Having been freed by the Parthians, Demetrius II of Syria recovers the throne of the Seleucid Empire.
Sempronius Tuditanus celebrates his triumph over the Iapydes of Illyria.
Autumn: Emperor Wu launches his first offensive into the northern steppe against the Xiongnu and their allies. The invasion consists of four armies, each of 10,000 cavalrymen.

The Han diplomat Zhang Qian escapes Xiongnu custody and resumes his mission of forming an anti-Xiongnu alliance with the Yuezhi. He reaches the State of Dayuan in the Ferghana Valley, whose trade with the Han had been prevented by the Xiongnu and who supply Zhang with guides.
Laudius Ptolemaeus tabulates angles of refraction for several media.
– – Antinous, from Hadrian's Villa at Tivoli, Italy, is made. It is now kept at Museo Gregoriano Egizio, Rome.
The Temple of Olympian Zeus is completed at Athens.
A Triumphal Arch for Hadrian is built in Gerasa.
The Scythian king Rudradaman I reconquers the lands annexed by Gautamiputra from the Andhra.
Roman census carried out by Quintus Pompeius and Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus.
Oncubine Wei Zifu gives birth to Liu Ju, the future Crown Prince.
Onsul Marcus Perperna defeats Aristonicus in battle, besieges him at Stratonicea, dies at Pergamon.
King Ptolemy VIII murders Ptolemy VII Neos Philopator or Ptolemy Memphites, the puppet ruler of Cleopatra II.
The tribune Gaius Papirius Carbo passes a measure allowing the use of secret ballots in legislative assemblies.

The Praetor's Edict is definitively codified by Salvius Julianus, on Hadrian's orders. This change means that senatorial decrees become a mere confirmation of the imperial speech (oratio principis) which initiated them.

The Edict of Hadrian prohibits the practice of circumcision. Additionally, Hadrian prohibits public reading of the Torah under penalty of death, as well as observance of festivals and the Sabbath, the teaching of Judaic Law, and the ordination of rabbis.
Italy is divided into legal districts managed by consuls, a direct blow to the power and prestige of the Senate.
The Temple of Baalshamin is built in Palmyra.
Hadrian restores the monarchist policy of Claudius and Domitian. The equestrian order is given full legal status, and attains the second order of the state.
During Aristonicus of Pergamon uprising against Rome, the consul Publius Licinius Crassus Mucianius is killed in the fighting.

The Roman censor Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus attempts to remove the tribune Gaius Atinius Labeo Macerio from the Senate, the angry Atinius drags him to be thrown off the Tarpeian Rock, and Metellus is only saved by the intervention of other senators.
For the first time in Roman history, both censors are plebeians (Metellus and Quintus Pompeius).
Legio X Fretensis must evacuate Jerusalem, returning to Caesarea. The Jews enter the city, and re-establish their system of sacrifices.

Bar Kokhba revolt: The messianic, charismatic Jewish leader Simon bar Kokhba starts a war of liberation for Judea against the Romans, which is eventually crushed by Emperor Hadrian; Rabbi Akiva is supportive of the rebellion.
Hange of era name from Yongjian (7th year) to Yangjia of the Chinese Han dynasty.

Merchants in Britain build structures outside the forts of Hadrian's Wall, and offer goods and services (including brothels) to Roman soldiers, who receive salaries in a region that otherwise has virtually no ready money.

Hinese scientist Zhang Heng invents the first seismometer for determining the exact cardinal direction of earthquakes hundreds of miles away; the device employs a series of complex gears around a central swinging pendulum.
The Late Formative (or pre-Classic) period of the Maya civilization begins.
The First Servile War ends when Publius Rupilius quelled the rebellion.

Bar Kokhba Revolt: Sextus Julius Severus, Roman governor of Britain, is sent to Judea (in renamed Syria Palaestina) to quell the revolt. Jewish rebels, led by Simon bar Kokhba and Eleazar, cut off the vital supply lines and Roman garrisons in Palestine.
Foreign Minister Wang Hui, who, against the opposition of Han Anguo, had advocated for war, fails to attack the retreating supply column of the Xiongnu and is sentenced to death. He commits suicide.
Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus, is elected tribune of the people. He attempts to pass a law to redistribute the public land to benefit small landowners.

June – A large army of the Han dynasty, under the overall command of Han Anguo, attempts to ambush the Xiongnu leader Junchen Chanyu in the Battle of Mayi. By pretending to betray the city of Mayi, a Han official had lured Junchen onto Han soil.
Scipio Aemilianus captures Numantia, after a siege of eight months, suffering famine and pestilence. The remnant population of 4,000 citizens, surrender and set their city on fire.
Lucius Calpurnius Piso Frugi, as consul, is sent against the slaves in Italy. Gaius Marius serves under Publius Cornelius Scipio Aemilianus at Numantia.
Arrianus, Roman governor of Cappadocia, repulses an attack of the Alani, a nomadic tribe from southeastern Russia.
A law improving the lot of free workers is passed in Rome.
Summer – Sextus Julius Severus, Roman governor of Judea, begins a campaign against the Jewish rebel strongholds in the mountains.
Ilseong becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Silla.
Hadrian's Villa in Tivoli, Italy, is completed.
Scipio Aemilianus, victor of Carthage, takes command in Spain against the Numantians. He recruits 20,000 men and,000 allies, including Numidian cavalry under Jugurtha.
Aius Fulvius Flaccus, as consul, is sent against the slaves. Uprising of 4,000 slaves crushed at Sinuessa, in Campania.
Hipparchus discovers the precession of the equinoxes.
John Hyrcanus becomes high priest and prince of Judea, until, following the murder of his father Simon Maccabaeus by Ptolemy the son of Abubus in.

On the advice of philosopher Dong Zhongshu, Emperor Wu of Han promotes Confucianism as the official doctrine of the Han dynasty and assigns special merit to the Book of Rites, the Classic of Music, the Classic of Poetry, the Book of Documents, I Ching (the Book of Changes) and the Spring and Autumn Annals.
Jerusalem is renamed Colonia Aelia Capitolina, in honor of Hadrian. Legio VI Ferrata rebuilds the legionary fortress in the city, and constructs a Roman temple at Golgotha.
Anopus, Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is finished.
Last year of Yangjia era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
Alans threaten Cappadocia; they are repulsed by Arrian.
A Jewish diaspora begins, as Emperor Hadrian bars Jews from Jerusalem, and has survivors of the massacre dispersed across the Roman Empire. Many join Mediterranean ports.
A Han military campaign against the Dian Kingdom establishes a military commandery in the Yunnan region.

Minyue attacks Nanyue, which are both vassal states of the Han dynasty. The Han send two armies against Minyue under Wang Hui and Han Anguo, and Minyue's king Zou Ying is killed by his brother Zou Yushan, who then surrenders to the Han.
Emperor Wu makes Zou Chou the king of Minyue, but Zou Yushan carves out two thirds of Minyue as the state of Dongyue, which Wu then recognizes.
Menander I, king of the Indo-Greek Kingdom dies and is succeeded by Epander.
Grand Empress Dowager Dou dies, which allows her grandson Emperor Wu to exert greater control over the empire.
First year of Yonghe era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
Hange of Bishop of Byzantium from Bishop Eleutherius to Bishop Felix.
The war against the Suebi begins.
Hadrian dictates his memoirs at his villa near Tivoli outside Rome.
The Roman province of Iudaea (plus Galilee) becomes Syria Palaestina; the name Palestine as a designation for this land has been used since at least the (mentioned by Herodotus).
Onfucianism is adopted as the state religion in China by Emperor Wu.
The Romans hand Gaius Hostilius Mancinus over to the Numantians in order to repudiate his peace treaty with them.
Ensorship of Appius Claudius Pulcher and Quintus Fulvius Nobilior.
Arneades retires as head of the Platonic Academy and is replaced by Polemarchus of Nicomedia.

In Jiaozhi (present-day northern Vietnam) during the Second Era of Northern Domination, a rebellion of the Cham people broke out and lasted for one year, until the peace agreement was made between the Han dynasty governors and the rebels in.
Tax laws are passed for trade in Palmyra. The caravan city grows rich by importing rare products from the Persian Gulf, and by exporting items manufactured by the Mediterranean world to the East.
Numantine War begins, Quintus Pompeius and M. Papilius Laenas are defeated and disgraced by the Numantians in subsequent years.
Tiberius Gracchus, quaestor in Spain, observes that slave labor has displaced small freeheld farms.
Q. Pompeius is brought to trial by Q.Metellus and others, but acquitted.
July 10 – Hadrian dies after a heart failure at Baiae, and is buried at Rome in the Gardens of Domitia beside his wife, Vibia Sabina.
February 25 – Emperor Hadrian makes Antoninus Pius his successor, on condition that he adopt Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus.
Antoninus Pius succeeds Hadrian as Roman Emperor, and asks the Senate to confer divine honors for Hadrian.

In Jiaozhi (present-day northern Vietnam), during the Second Era of Northern Domination, a peace agreement was made between the Han governor and the Cham rebels following their uprising in. Historical records do not clarify the terms of the agreement.
Onstruction begins on the Theater of Philadelphia.
Hymn to Apollo is written and inscribed on stone in Delphi; it is the earliest surviving notated music, in a substantial and legible fragment, in the western world.
Attalus III succeeds Attalus II as Attalid king of Pergamon.
Phraates II becomes emperor of Parthia.
Tautalus surrenders to the Romans.
Antiochus VII expels Diodotus Tryphon.
Antoninus Pius and Gaius Bruttius Praesens become Roman Consuls.
Marcus Aurelius is named Caesar. He marries the 9-year-old Faustina the Younger, daughter of Antoninus Pius.

The Tomb of Hadrian in Rome is completed; Emperor Antoninus Pius cremates the body of Hadrian, and places his ashes, together with that of his wife Vibia Sabina and his adopted son, Lucius Aelius, in the mausoleum.
Mcurn earthquake, listed in bibliographical records of seismology as having affected the city of Mcurn (modern Hösnek, Turkey). The earthquake reportedly took place in the vicinity of Mount Ararat.
Soon after his departure for the west, Zhang Qian is detained by Junchen Chanyu of the Xiongnu. He would remain in Xiongnu custody for more than ten years and would be given a Xiongnu wife.

Wei Zifu enters Emperor Wu's palace as a concubine and becomes pregnant. Enraged, Liu Piao, the mother of the childless Empress Chen Jiao (wife of Emperor Wu), kidnaps Zifu's brother Wei Qing, who is rescued by Gongsun Ao.
Hipparchus makes a very precise determination of the length of the synodic month.

Emperor Wu of Han sends the diplomat Zhang Qian west to form an alliance with the Yuezhi against the Xiongnu. Wu does this after learning from Xiongnu defectors that the Xiongnu had defeated and killed the king of the Yuezhi, had expelled the Yuezhi from their lands and were using their king's skull as a wine goblet.
The Lusitanian War ends when the rebellion collapses after the assassination of Viriathus by a Roman agent.
Antoninus Pius recognizes the king of the Quadi, who becomes an ally of Rome.
Emperor Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar become Roman Consuls.
Ptolemy completes his Almagest (approximate date).
King Mithridates V dies; Vologases IV claims the throne and extends his rule throughout the Parthian Empire.
Pope Pius I succeeds Pope Hyginus as the tenth pope of Rome according to tradition.
Scipio Aemilianus leads a group of Roman ambassadors to Alexandria, where they meet with King Ptolemy VIII.
Simon Maccabaeus crowned king of Judea.
The Lycia earthquake affects most of the Roman provinces of Lycia and Caria and the islands of Rhodes, Kos, Simi and Serifos. It triggers a severe tsunami, which causes major inundation.
The Temple of Antoninus and Faustina is constructed in Rome; the temple is dedicated to Empress Faustina the Elder.
Hange of Patriarch of Constantinople from Felix of Byzantium to Polycarpus II of Byzantium.
6th recorded perihelion passage of Halley's Comet.
Last year of Yonghe era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
March 9 – Emperor Wu of Han ("Martial Emperor") starts to rule the Han dynasty.
Demetrius II of Syria made prisoner of Mithridates, king of the Parthians. Antiochus VII Sidetes becomes king of the Seleucid Empire in his absence.
Yuezhi refugees appear on the borders of the Greco-Bactrian kingdom.
The Seleucid garrison negotiates the surrender of Jerusalem. Simon Maccabaeus assumes control of the city.
Marcion proclaims that the Old Testament is incompatible with Christianity.
Municipal doctors are named throughout the Roman Empire.
The Chinese Taoist alchemist Wei Boyang, author of the Kinship of the Three, is the first to describe an early form of gunpowder solution.

Emperor Antoninus Pius orders the construction of the Antonine Wall. The wall stretches 39 miles, from Old Kilpatrick in West Dunbartonshire on the Firth of Clyde, to Carriden near Bo'ness on the Firth of Forth.
First year of the Hanan era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
Diodotus Tryphon seizes the throne of the Seleucid Empire.
Simon Maccabaeus succeeds his brother Jonathan as High Priest of Judea until.
A revolt of the Brigantes tribe in Britannia is suppressed by Quintus Lollius Urbicus.
The Roman doctor Antyllus performs the first arteriotomy.
Antoninus Pius serves as Roman Consul.
The Celtiberian War ends when Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus crushes the rebels.
The Roman campaigns in Mauretania begin.
Hange of emperor from Han Shundi to Han Chongdi of the Han dynasty.
Marcion of Sinope is excommunicated; a sect, Marcionism, grows out of his beliefs.
Reign of Huvishka, emperor of the Kushan Empire.
In Vietnam during the second Era of Northern Domination, rebellion of Cham people broke out in Jiaozhi and Jiuzhen. The rebels then surrendered to the Jiaozhi's governor in the same year.
Quintus Marcius Rex starts construction of the Aqua Marcia aqueduct in Rome.
Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar become Roman Consuls.
Hange of emperor from Han Chongdi to Han Zhidi of the Chinese Han dynasty.
Marcus Aurelius marries Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius.
Arrian becomes archon in Athens.
In the Battle of Antioch, Ptolemy VI Philometor defeats the Seleucid usurper Alexander Balas, but dies in the battle.
Hipparchus determines the length of the tropical year.
Ptolemy VII becomes king of Egypt briefly, then is assassinated by Ptolemy VIII the following year.
Marcus Aurelius receives the imperium proconsular.
Faustina the Younger is given the title Augusta, and becomes Roman Empress.
Hange of era name from Yongxi (1st year) to Benchu era of the Chinese Han dynasty.
Han Huandi succeeds Han Zhidi as emperor of the Chinese Han dynasty.
Hadae becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
Hipparchus determines the equinoctial point.
Battle of Corinth: The Romans under Lucius Mummius defeat the Achaean League near Corinth. Corinth is destroyed, and the Achaean League dissolved.
Spring – Carthage falls to Roman forces under Scipio Aemilianus and the city is completely destroyed. End of the Third Punic War.
Roman armies destroy Carthage and Corinth.
Achaean War: The Romans conquer the Achaean League and southern Greece becomes a Roman province.
Marcus Aurelius receives imperial powers, from Emperor Antoninus Pius.
Festivals to celebrate the 900th anniversary of the founding of Rome begin.
King Vologases III dies after a 42-year reign, in which he has contended successfully with his rivals.
First year of Jianhe of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
King Vologases IV, son of Mithridates V of Parthia, unites the Parthian Empire under his rule.
In Lusitania, Hispania, the Celtic king Viriathus, rallies Lusitanian resistance to Rome.
Despite being the five years below the minimum age required, Scipio Aemilianus is elected Consul under popular pressure.
Demetrius II of Syria returns to Syria (approximate date).
Emperor Antoninus Pius hosts a series of grand games, to celebrate Rome's 900th anniversary.
Euzois succeeds Athendodorus, as Patriarch of Constantinople.
Onstruction of the Via Postumia, linking Aquileia and Genua.
Publius Cornelius Scipio Aemilianus divides Numidia among the three sons of the recently deceased Masinissa.
With the defeat of Andriscus in the Battle of Pydna by Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus, Macedon is reorganized as a Roman province by.
Orlea Trackway built in County Longford.
With Roman help, Nicomedes II overthrows his father Prusias II as king of Bithynia.
Lucius Calpurnius Piso passes the lex Calpurnia de repetundis which establishes the first permanent criminal court in Rome.
The turmoil in Spain escalates again with the renewal of the Lusitanian War, under the leadership of Viriathus, and the Celtiberian War.
Servius Sulpicius Galba is prosecuted for corruption while serving in Spain, but is acquitted after he parades his weeping family members before the tribunal.
The Third Punic War begins. The Romans land an army in Africa to begin the Battle of Carthage.
Antoninus Liberalis writes a work on mythology (Μεταμορφωσεων Συναγωγη) (approximate date).
The Roman town Forum Hadriani receives the title of Municipium Aelium Cananefatium, "the town of the Cananefates" (modern Netherlands). The town is awarded with rights to organize markets.
The Great Pyramid of the Sun is constructed in Teotihuacan. It is the tallest pre-Columbian building in the Americas.
The earliest atlas (Ptolemy's Geography) is made (approximate date).
Marcion of Sinope produces his Bible canon, consisting of purged versions of the Gospel of Luke and ten Pauline letters (approximate date).
The enlargement of the Great Stupa of Sanchi, Madhya Pradesh, India begins, taking about some years.

The Roman Senate shows displeasure with Carthage's decision to wage war against its neighbour without Roman consent, and tells Carthage that in order to avoid a war it has to "satisfy the Roman People". The Roman censor, Cato the Elder, urges the destruction of Carthage and the Roman Senate orders the gathering of an army.

Nicomedes, the son of king Prusias II of Bithynia, who has been sent to Rome to argue for smaller reparations arising from his father's unsuccessful war against Pergamum, gains the support of the Roman Senate to the point where Prusias sends an emissary with secret orders to assassinate Nicomedes. However, the emissary reveals the plot to Nicomedes and persuades him to rebel against his father.
The making of the statue Hellenistic Ruler begins and is finished ten years later. It is now kept at the Museo Nazionale Romano in Rome.

The pretender to the Seleucid throne, Alexander Balas, who claims to be the son of the late Antiochus IV, defeats the Seleucid king, Demetrius I Soter, in battle and kills him. The Roman Senate, along with Attalus II Philadelphus of Pergamum and Ptolemy VI Philometor of Egypt, support Alexander Balas and he becomes the ruler of the Seleucid Empire.
First year of Yuanjia of the Chinese Han dynasty.
Mytilene and Smyrna are destroyed by an earthquake.
Detail from a rubbing of a stone relief in Wu family shrine, Jiaxiang, Shandong, is made (Han dynasty).
Roman forces help the thriving Greek commercial port of Massilia combat raids from the Celts from Cisalpine Gaul.
Agnimitra succeeds his father Pushyamitra Shunga as emperor of the Shunga dynasty.

At Polybius' request, Scipio Aemilianus manages to gain the support of the Roman statesman Cato the Elder (whose son has married Scipio's sister Aemilia) for a proposal to release (and return to Greece) the 300 Achaean internees who are still being held without trial after being deported to Rome in.

Roman armies under the leadership of praetor Servius Sulpicius Galba and the proconsul Lucius Licinius Lucullus arrive in Hispania Ulterior and begin the process of subduing the local population. The revolt of the Celtiberians of Numantia is stopped.

The Carthaginian debt to Rome is fully repaid, meaning that, according to Carthage, the treaty with Rome, which was put in place at the end of the Second Punic War, is no longer in force. The Romans do not agree with this interpretation.
The Chinese domination of the Tarim Basin weakens.

The pretender to the Seleucid throne, Alexander Balas, makes contact with Jonathan Maccabeus offering him terms even more favorable than those offered by the king Demetrius I Soter. In particular, Alexander offers him the official appointment as High Priest in Jerusalem.
Hange of era name from Yuanjia (3rd year) to Yongxing of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
Minor uprisings occur in Roman Egypt against Roman rule.

The Seleucid king Demetrius I Soter's relations with Attalus II Philadelphus of Pergamum and Ptolemy VI Philometor of Egypt deteriorate to the point where they support a rival claimant to the Syrian throne, Alexander Balas, who claims to be the son of the former Seleucid king Antiochus IV Epiphanes and, therefore, a first cousin of Demetrius. He has been "discovered" by Heracleides, a former minister of Antiochus IV and brother of Timarchus, who has been executed by Demetrius I Soter in after leading a revolt against him in Media.

As a result of the rise of the pretender, Alexander Balas, Demetrius I Soter is forced to recall most of his garrisons in Judea. To retain control of Judea, he makes a bid to gain the loyalty of Jonathan Maccabeus, whom he permits to recruit an army and to take back the hostages that the Syrians are holding in the city of Acre.
Substantial parts of the city of Sikyon are destroyed by an earthquake.

The uprisings in Rome's Hispanic provinces oblige the year's consuls to take office earlier than the traditional date of 15 March, a change that becomes permanent. Some suggest that, as a consequence, January 1 becomes the first day of the Roman year.
Last year of Yongxing era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
Adalla becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Silla.
Hange of Patriarch of Constantinople from Patriarch Euzois to Patriarch Laurence.
Anicetus meets with Polycarp of Smyrna to discuss the Computus, the date of Easter in the Christian liturgical calendar.
King Eupator of Bosphorus pays tribute to Rome, due to the threat posed by the Alani.

After a two-year struggle, Attalus II Philadelphus of Pergamum is finally able to defeat Prusias II, the aggressive king of Bithynia in northern Anatolia. He is assisted in his battle against Prusias II by Ariarathes V of Cappadocia (who has sent his son Demetrius to command his forces) and by the Romans.

The Egyptian king Ptolemy VI Philometor defeats his brother, Ptolemy VIII Euergetes, after he attempts to seize Cyprus by force. Nevertheless Philometor restores his brother to Cyrenaica, marries one of his daughters to him, and grants him a grain subsidy.

After his victory, Attalus II insists on heavy reparations from Prusias II. In response, Prusias II sends his son Nicomedes to Rome to ask the Romans' help in reducing the amount of these reparations.
The Lusitanians harry the inhabitants of the Roman provinces in Hispania. At the same time, the Celtiberians of Numantia on the Douro revolt against their Roman occupation.

The Rebellion of the Seven States against the Han dynasty fails and Emperor Jing of Han further consolidates his power at the expense of the regional, semi-autonomous kings governing the eastern portion of the empire.
The Council of Rome, a pre-ecumenical church council, is held and presided over by Bishop of Rome Anicetus.
Under the command of Punicus and then Caesarus, the Lusitani, a Hispanic tribe, reach a point near modern day Gibraltar. Here they are defeated by the Roman praetor Lucius Mummius.

As part of the Roman efforts to fully conquer and occupy the whole of Illyria, a Roman army under consul Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica Corculum attacks the Dalmatians for the first time and conquers the Dalmatian capital of Delminium. As a result, the Dalmatians are compelled to pay tribute to Rome, which puts an end to the first Dalmatian war.

Menander I (known as Milinda in Sanskrit and Pali) begins his reign as king of the Indo-Greek Kingdom. His territories cover the eastern dominions of the divided Greek empire of Bactria (Panjshir and Kapisa) and extend to the modern Pakistani province of Punjab, most of the Indian states of Punjab and Himachal Pradesh and the Jammu region.
The heresiarch Montanus first appears in Ardaban.
The La Mojarra Stela 1 is produced in Mesoamerica.
The first Dalmatian war begins.

In Jiuzhen (modern day Northern Vietnam), during the second Era of Northern Domination, a rebellion led by Chu Đạt breaks out and lasts for two to three years, until it is quelled by the Han Dynasty, under emperor Huan.
A revolt against Roman rule begins in Dacia.

The Carthaginians, prevented by their treaty with Rome from engaging in armed resistance, but equally guaranteed against any loss of territory, appeal to Rome against the depredations of King Masinissa of Numidia. The Roman censor Marcus Porcius Cato heads a commission which arbitrates a truce between Carthage and her former ally, Masinissa.
Jonathan Maccabeus is recognised by the Seleucids as a minor king within their dominions.

During his time in Carthage, Cato is so struck by the evidence of Carthaginian prosperity that he is convinced that the security of Rome now depends on the annihilation of Carthage. From this time on, Cato keeps repeating the cry "Ceterum censeo Carthaginem esse delendam" ("Moreover, I advise that Carthage must be destroyed") at the end of all his speeches, no matter what subject they concern.

After Ariarathes V has been deposed from the Cappadocian throne by the Seleucid king Demetrius I Soter and has fled to Rome, the new king of Cappadocia, Orophernes, sends two ambassadors to Rome to join the Seleucid emissaries of Demetrius in opposing Ariarathes V's return to power. Despite their efforts, Ariarathes V is restored to his throne by the Romans.
A revolt against Roman rule in Dacia is crushed.
The earliest dated use of Sol Invictus, in a dedication from Rome.
Hange of era name from Yongshou to Yangxi of the Chinese Han dynasty.

At the request of the Romans, Ariarathes V, king of Cappadocia, rejects a proposal from the Seleucid king, Demetrius I, for him to marry the sister of Demetrius I. In response, Seleucid forces attack Cappadocia and remove Ariarathes V from the Cappadocian throne.
In India, the reign of Shivashri Satakarni, as King Satavahana of Andhra, begins.

With the Seleucid victory in Judea over the Maccabees, Alcimus is re-established as the High Priest of Israel, and a strong force is left in Jerusalem to support him. However, he does not enjoy his triumph for long, as he dies soon after from a paralytic stroke.

While Eucratides I is in north west India to claim possession of the previous Bactrian King Demetrius I's territory there, the Parthians, under Mithradates I, annex two Bactrian provinces. Returning from India to reconquer them, Eucratides is murdered by his son.
Attalus II Philadelphus succeeds his brother Eumenes II as king of Pergamon.
The first Buddhist monks arrive in China.
In Roman Empire, the Antonine Wall in Britain is retaken by Roman legions.
Appian writes Ρωμαικα, known in English as the Roman History, in which he includes the history of each nation conquered up until the moment of its conquest.

In Jiuzhen (modern day Northern Vietnam) during the second Era of Northern Domination, a rebellion broke out but was swiftly quelled when the rebels surrendered to the newly appointed governor of Jiaozhi, who had previously governed the commandery in the 140s.
In Rome, the manufacturing of soap containing grease, lime and ashes begins.
The Seleucid king, Demetrius I Soter defeats a Jewish rebellion at Palestine.

Demetrius I defeats and kills the rebel general Timarchus and is recognized as king of the Seleucid empire by the Roman Senate. Demetrius acquires his surname of Soter (meaning Saviour) from the Babylonians, for delivering them from the tyranny of Timarchus.
The Parthian King, Mithradates I, seizes Media from the Seleucids following the death of Timarchus.

The king of Bactria, Eucratides I, is considered to have killed Apollodotus I, an Indo-Greek king who rules the western and southern parts of the Indo-Greek kingdom, when he invades the western territories of that kingdom.
Judas Maccabeus is succeeded as army commander and leader of the Maccabees by his younger brother, Jonathan Maccabeus.

Marcus Aurelius, a Spaniard like Trajan and Hadrian, is a stoical disciple of Epictetus, and an energetic man of action. He pursues the policy of his predecessor and maintains good relations with the Senate.
March 7 – Emperor Antoninus Pius dies, and is succeeded by Marcus Aurelius, who shares imperial power with Lucius Verus, although Marcus retains the title Pontifex Maximus.
Aurelius reduces the weight of a goldpiece, the aureus, from 7. grams to 7.12 grams.
Autumn – The Parthians invade Armenia, and install their own candidate on the throne. A legion (perhaps Legio IX Hispana) is destroyed at Elegeia.
The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to percent under Emperor Marcus Aurelius, down from percent under Antoninus Pius.
The Roman playwright Terence's plays Eunuchus (The Eunuch) and Phormio are first performed.

The rebel Seleucid general and ruler of Media, Timarchus, who has distinguished himself by defending Media against the emergent Parthians, treats Demetrius I's violent accession to the Seleucid throne as the excuse to declare himself an independent king and extend his realm from Media into Babylonia.
The Maccabees, led by Judas Maccabeus, and a Seleucid army, led by the Seleucid general Nicanor, fight the Battle of Adasa, near Beth-horon. Maccabeus wins the battle and Nicanor is killed.
Marcus Pomponius, praetor in, obtains a decree of the senate, forbidding philosophers and rhetoricians from living in Rome.

With the restoration of peace in Judea, an internal struggle breaks out between the supporters of Judas Maccabeus and the Hellenic party. The influence of the Hellenic Party all but collapses in the wake of the Seleucid defeat.
Arrian, Greek historian and writer, publishes Indica, a work on India and its people.
Lucius Verus begins a war with the Parthians, due to the invasion of Syria and Armenia by King Vologases IV of Parthia.
The Maccabees, under the leadership of Judas Maccabeus, continue their struggle against the Seleucids and persecute the Hellenising faction in Judea.

Seleucid forces still control the Acra, a strong fortress within Jerusalem that faces the Temple Mount.
