The Pennsylvania Railroad and the New York Central Railroad merge to form Penn Central, the largest ever corporate merger up to this date.
June 5 – Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy: Senator Robert F.
Nigerian forces capture Port Harcourt and form a ring around the Biafrans. This contributes to a humanitarian disaster as the surrounded population already suffers from hunger and starvation.

Vietnam War: At the apartment of French intermediary Jean Sainteny in Paris, U.S. representative Henry Kissinger and North Vietnamese representative Xuan Thuy begin secret peace negotiations. They eventually fail since the two sides cannot agree to any terms.
May 30 – Riots in Curaçao mark the start of an Afro-Caribbean civil rights movement on the island.
October 21 Willy Brandt becomes Chancellor of West Germany. General Siad Barre comes to power in Somalia in a coup, 6 days after the assassination of President Abdirashid Ali Shermarke.

March 3 Apollo program: NASA launches Apollo 9 (James McDivitt, Rusty Schweickart, David Scott) to test the lunar module. In a Los Angeles court, Sirhan Sirhan admits that he killed presidential candidate Robert F.
February 24 – The Mariner 6 Mars probe is launched from the United States.
December 28 – The suspected killers of Pierre Laporte, Jacques and Paul Rose and Francis Sunard, are arrested near Montreal.
July 21 – The Aswan High Dam in Egypt is completed.
Pope Paul VI names Saint Teresa of Ávila (d. 1582) as the first female Doctor of the Church.
Vietnam War: In Paris, a Communist delegation rejects U.S. President Richard Nixon's peace proposal as "a maneuver to deceive world opinion.".
September 9 – Guinea recognizes the German Democratic Republic.
A partial solar eclipse is visible from Asia and North America, and is the 70th and final solar eclipse of Solar Saros 116.
May 22 – An earthquake lasting 20 seconds destroys most of Bingöl, Turkey; more than 1,000 are killed and 10,000 are made homeless.

August 30 – The Progressive Conservatives under Peter Lougheed defeat the Social Credit government under Harry E. Strom in a general election, ending 36 years of uninterrupted power for Social Credit in Alberta.
International Telecommunications Satellite Organization (effective February 12, ).
February 28 – Evel Knievel sets a world record and jumps 19 cars on a motorbike in Ontario, California.
Seven men and three women hijack a plane from Czechoslovakia to West Germany.
Imelda Marcos, First Lady of the Philippines, is stabbed and seriously wounded by an assailant; her bodyguards shoot the assailant.
May 7 – General elections are held in Italy.
March 19 – India and Bangladesh sign the Indo-Bangladeshi Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Peace.
A collision between two trains near Seville, Spain, kills 76 people.
The Sydney Opera House in Australia is opened by Queen Elizabeth II after 14 years of construction work.
November 27 – The United States Senate votes 92–3 to confirm Gerald Ford as Vice President of the United States.

July 5 – The catastrophic BLEVE (Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion) occurs in Kingman, Arizona, United States, following a fire that broke out as propane was being transferred from a railroad car to a storage tank, killing 11 firefighters. This explosion becomes a classic incident, studied in fire department training programs worldwide.
September 9 – Scottish racing driver Jackie Stewart becomes World Drivers' Champion when his Tyrrell 003-Cosworth finishes fourth in the Italian Grand Prix at Monza.
July 11 – Varig Flight 820 crashes near Orly, France; 123 people are killed.
Watergate scandal: August 8 – U.S. President Richard Nixon announces his resignation on August 8, effective at noon on August 9.
December 17 – The World Intellectual Property Organization becomes a specialized agency of the United Nations.

October 11 – The UK Labour government of Harold Wilson wins the second general election of the year, forming a three-seat majority. Wilson, who has led the party for a total of 11 years, has now won four of the five general elections he has contested.
TWA Flight 841 crashes into the Ionian Sea 18 minutes after takeoff from Athens on an Israel–New York flight after a bomb explodes in the cargo hold, and kills 88 people.
April 6 – Swedish pop group ABBA's song "Waterloo" wins the Eurovision Song Contest in Brighton, England, UK.
Suriname gains independence from the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
May 3 – West Ham United win the FA Cup at Wembley, beating Fulham 2–0 in the final.
Founder President Sheikh Mujibur Rahman of Bangladesh is killed during a coup led by Major Syed Faruque Rahman.
May 27 – The Dibbles Bridge coach crash near Grassington, North Yorkshire, England, results in 32 deaths (the highest toll in a United Kingdom road accident).

November 28 Portuguese Timor declares its independence from Portugal as East Timor. South African Navy frigates evacuate 26 SADF members from behind enemy lines at Ambrizete, 160 kilometres (99 mi) north of Luanda in Angola.
The Conference of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe convenes in East Berlin.
September 6 Cold War: Soviet Air Force pilot Lt. Viktor Belenko lands a MiG-25 jet fighter at Hakodate, on the island of Hokkaidō in Japan, and requests political asylum in the United States.
October 22 – Cearbhall Ó Dálaigh, the 5th President of Ireland, resigns after being publicly insulted by the Minister for Defense.
U.S. President Gerald Ford signs the Federal Election Campaign Act.
April 19 – A violent F5 tornado strikes around Brownwood, Texas, injuring 11 people. Two people were thrown at least 1,000 yards (910 m) by the tornado and survived uninjured.

July 1 The East African Community is dissolved. The Championships, Wimbledon – Virginia Wade wins the women's singles title in the centenary year of the tournament, Wade's first and only Wimbledon title and her third and final Grand Slam title overall; she remains the last British woman to win the singles title at Wimbledon.
June 15 – Spain has its first democratic elections, after 41 years of Francoist Spain.
January 23 – Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India calls for fresh elections to the Lok Sabha, and releases all political prisoners.

September 19 Under pressure from the Carter Administration, President of Nicaragua Anastasio Somoza Debayle lifts the state of siege in Nicaragua. North Korean agents abduct Yutaka Kume from Noto Peninsula starting the North Korean abductions of Japanese citizens.
September 4 – The Golden Dragon massacre, involving rival Chinatown gangs, takes place in San Francisco, United States. Five are killed.

March 26 – The control tower and some other facilities of New Tokyo International Airport, which were scheduled to open on March 31, are illegally occupied and damaged in a terrorist attack by New Left activists, forcing a rescheduling of its opening date to May 20.
September 28 – Pope John Paul I dies after only 33 days as the Roman Catholic Pontiff.
April 22 Izhar Cohen & the Alphabeta win the Eurovision Song Contest for Israel with their song A-Ba-Ni-Bi. The One Love Peace Concert is held at National Heroes Stadium in Kingston, Jamaica.
Stump v. Sparkman (435 U.S. 349): The Supreme Court of the United States hands down a 5–3 decision, in a controversial case involving involuntary sterilization and judicial immunity.
Police in the West Midlands of England launch a massive murder hunt, when 13-year-old newspaper boy Carl Bridgewater is shot dead after disturbing a burglary.
The One-child policy is introduced in China – it contributes to the country's sex-ratio imbalance. It was loosened in.

The NATO Double-Track Decision: is the decision of NATO from December 12,, to offer the Warsaw Pact a mutual limitation of medium-range ballistic missiles and intermediate-range ballistic missiles combined with the threat that in case of disagreement NATO would deploy more middle-range nuclear weapons in Western Europe, following the so-called "Euromissile Crisis".

March 26 In a ceremony at the White House, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel sign an Egypt–Israel peace treaty. Michigan State University, led by Earvin "Magic" Johnson, defeats Larry Bird-led Indiana State 75–64 in the NCAA tournament championship game at Salt Lake City.

January 7 – Cambodian–Vietnamese War: The People's Army of Vietnam and Vietnamese-backed Cambodian insurgents announce the fall of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and the collapse of the Pol Pot regime. Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge retreat west to an area along the Thai border, ending large-scale fighting.
May 1 – Greenland is granted limited autonomy from Denmark, with its own Parliament sitting in Nuuk.
The Elisabeth blast furnace is demolished at Bilston Steelworks, marking the end of iron and steel production in the Black Country region of the U.K.
August 7–31 – Lech Wałęsa leads the first of many strikes at the Gdańsk Shipyard in the Polish People's Republic.
April 1 – The Southern African Development Coordination Conference is formed in Lusaka, Zambia.
May 28 – A fiery bus crash near the small village of Webb, Saskatchewan, Canada, claims 22 lives.
March 8 – The Soviet Union's first rock music festival starts.
July 3 – The Toxteth riots in Liverpool, England, start after a mob prevents a youth from being arrested. Shortly afterward, the Chapeltown riots in Leeds start amid increased racial tension.
April 11 – Brixton riot: Rioters in south London, UK, throw petrol bombs, attack police and loot shops.

August 30 – Iranian Prime Minister's office bombing: Eight people, including the country's president and prime minister, are killed when a briefcase explodes in the building. The office of Iran's Prosecutor General blames the People's Mujahedin of Iran.
Use of crack cocaine, a smokeable form of the drug, first reported in the United States and Caribbean.
October 16 – Gas explosions at a coal mine at Hokutan, Yūbari, Hokkaidō, Japan, kill 93 people.

University of California, Berkeley executes "The Play" in a college football game against Stanford. Completing a wacky 57-yard kickoff return that includes five laterals, Kevin Moen runs through Stanford band members who have prematurely come onto the field.
September 25 – In Israel, 400,000 marchers demand the resignation of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.
Falklands War: British troops retake South Georgia Island during Operation Paraquet.
March 10 The United States places an embargo on Libyan oil imports, alleging Libyan state-sponsored terrorism. Syzygy: All 9 planets recognized at this time align on the same side of the Sun.
December 8 – The December murders occur in Suriname.
Heavy rain and mudslides in western Shimane Prefecture, Japan, kill 117.

November 7 Able Archer 83: Many Soviet officials misinterpret this NATO exercise as a nuclear first strike, causing the last nuclear scare of the Cold War. U.S. Senate bombing: A bomb explodes in the United States Senate with the intent to kill Republican senators; no one is injured.
February 16 – The Ash Wednesday bushfires in Victoria and South Australia claim the lives of 75 people, in one of Australia's worst bushfire disasters.
June 5 – The Second Sudanese Civil War begins in Sudan.
April 18 The United States embassy bombing in Beirut kills 63 people. The Disney Channel launches in the United States.

November 6 – United States presidential election: Republican President Ronald Reagan defeats Democratic former Vice President Walter F. Mondale with 59% of the popular vote, the highest since Richard Nixon's 61% popular vote victory in.
April 12 – Palestinian gunmen take Israeli bus number 300 hostage. Israeli special forces storm the bus, freeing the hostages (one hostage, two hijackers killed).

April 17 – Metropolitan Police officer Yvonne Fletcher was fatally shot, during a demonstration outside the Libyan embassy in London, leading to an eleven-day siege of the embassy, and the severing of diplomatic relations between the United Kingdom and Libya.
August 30 – STS-41-D: the Space Shuttle Discovery takes off on its maiden voyage.
STS-41-D: the Space Shuttle Discovery lands after its maiden voyage at Edwards Air Force Base in California.
Hina Airlines Flight 006 is involved in a mid-air incident; while there are 22 minor injuries and 2 serious injuries, no one is killed.
American naturalist Dian Fossey is found brutally murdered in Rwanda.
Mohamed Al-Fayed buys the London-based department store company Harrods.
July 13 – Live Aid benefit concerts in London and Philadelphia raise over £50 million for famine relief in Ethiopia.
January 15 – Tancredo Neves is elected president of Brazil by the Congress, ending the 21-year military rule.

December 4 The MV Amazon Venture oil tanker begins leaking oil while at the port of Savannah in the United States, resulting in an oil spill of approximately 500,000 US gallons (1,900,000 L). 29 people are killed in the Pozzetto massacre.

People Power Revolution: President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines is ousted from power and goes into exile in Hawaii after 20 years of dictatorial rule; Corazon Aquino becomes the first Filipino woman president and forms an interim government with Salvador Laurel becoming her Vice-president and Prime Minister.

October 3 TASCC, a superconducting cyclotron, officially opens at Chalk River Laboratories. A hybrid solar eclipse was visible off the coast of Iceland, and was the 53rd solar eclipse of Solar Saros 124.
The MV Amazon Venture oil tanker begins leaking oil while at the port of Savannah in the United States, resulting in an oil spill of approximately 500,000 US gallons (1,900,000 L).
The cargo ship Khian Sea departs from the docks of Philadelphia, carrying 14,000 tons of toxic waste. It wanders the seas for the next 16 months trying to find a place to dump its cargo.
November 15 – In Brașov, Romania, workers rebel against the communist regime led by Nicolae Ceaușescu.

August 7 The Colombian frigate Caldas enters Venezuelan waters near the Los Monjes Archipelago, sparking the Caldas frigate crisis between both nations. American Lynne Cox becomes the first person to swim the Bering Strait, crossing from Little Diomede Island to Big Diomede in 2 hours and 5 minutes.
March 18 – Woodstock of physics: A marathon session of the American Physical Society's meeting features 51 presentations concerning the science of high-temperature superconductors.
October 7 Sikh nationalists declare the independence of Khalistan from India. The U.S.

March 28 – The Aegean crisis, which occurred near the Greek island of Thasos, was a confrontation between Greece and Turkey that was ultimately resolved peacefully. Turkey agreed to withdraw its vessels under the condition of Greece not pursue oil drills beyond its territorial waters.
March 25 – The Candle demonstration in Bratislava, Slovakia, is the first mass demonstration of the 1980s against the socialist government in Czechoslovakia.
March 20 – Eritrean War of Independence: Having defeated the Nadew Command, the EPLF enters the town of Afabet, victoriously concluding the Battle of Afabet.
Israeli–Palestinian conflict: An independent State of Palestine is proclaimed at the Palestinian National Council meeting in Algiers, by a vote of 253–46.
June 23 – NASA scientist James Hansen testifies to the U.S. Senate that human-made global warming has begun, becoming one of the first environmentalists to warn of the problem.
In the Geneva Accords, the Soviet Union commits itself to withdrawal of its forces from Afghanistan.
November 22 – In West Beirut, a bomb explodes near the motorcade of Lebanese President René Moawad, killing him.
May 14 Mikhail Gorbachev visits China, the first Soviet leader to do so since Nikita Khrushchev in the 1960s, ending the Sino-Soviet split. Carlos Menem wins the Argentine presidential election.
The Breguet Alizé propeller-driven anti-submarine planes are retired from active carrier service in the French Navy.
Gaby Kennard becomes the first Australian woman to fly solo around the world.
October 19 – The Guildford Four are freed after fourteen years' imprisonment in Britain.
December 23 – In the Slovenian independence referendum, 88.5% of the overall electorate (94.8% of votes), with the turnout of 93.3%, support independence of the country.
Pope John Paul II begins an eight-day tour of Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Burkina Faso, and Chad.
April 22 Lebanon hostage crisis: Lebanese kidnappers release American educator Robert Polhill, who had been held hostage since January. Earth Day 20 is celebrated by millions worldwide.
The Dinamo–Red Star riot took place at Stadion Maksimir in Zagreb, Croatia between the Bad Blue Boys (fans of GNK Dinamo Zagreb) and the Delije (fans of Red Star Belgrade).

March 18 Twelve paintings and a Shang dynasty vase, collectively worth $100 to $300 million, are stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, Massachusetts by two thieves posing as police officers. This is the largest art theft in US history, and the paintings (as of May ) have not been recovered.
December 11 – Dissolution of Yugoslavia: Croatian forces kill 18 Serbs and one Hungarian in the village of Paulin Dvor, Croatia.
May 28 – Ethiopian Civil War: The forces of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front seize the capital Addis Ababa.
July 18 – The governments of Mauritania and Senegal sign a treaty ending the Mauritania–Senegal Border War, which has been fought since April.
September 22 – The Huntington Library makes the Dead Sea Scrolls available to the public for the first time.
October 13 – In the Bulgarian parliamentary election, the Union of Democratic Forces defeats the Bulgarian Socialist Party, leaving no remaining Communist governments in Eastern Europe.

January 7 – European Community Monitor Mission helicopter downing: A Yugoslav Air Force Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 attacks two Italian Army Agusta-Bell AB-206L LongRanger helicopters carrying observers from the European Community Monitor Mission. One crashes, killing five people on board.
June 3–14 – The Earth Summit is held in Rio de Janeiro.
February 16 – In Lebanon, Israeli helicopter gunships assassinate Abbas al-Musawi, the leader of Hezbollah, and his son, in retaliation for a February 14 raid that killed three Israeli soldiers.

In a national referendum related to abortion, voters in Ireland reject the proposed Twelfth Amendment of the Constitution Bill but approve the Thirteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland.
The Nagorno-Karabakh Republic is proclaimed by the Armenians of Nagorno-Karabakh.
The Finisterre earthquakes in Papua New Guinea kill at least 60 due to landslides.
January 7 – The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated, with Jerry Rawlings as president.
The Chemical Weapons Convention is signed by President George H. W.
Attack on Pakistani military in Somalia: twenty-four Pakistani troops in the United Nations forces are killed in Mogadishu, Somalia.
Following a rash of integrist murders (including those of foreigners), Algeria breaks diplomatic relations with Iran, accusing the country of interfering in its interior affairs.
May 10 – Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president.
September 5 – New South Wales State MP for Cabramatta John Newman is shot outside his home, in Australia's first political assassination since.
March 6 – A referendum in Moldova results in the electorate voting against possible reunification with Romania.
March 20 – Italian journalist Ilaria Alpi and TV cameraman Miran Hrovatin are assassinated in Somalia.
American boxer George Foreman wins the WBA and IBF World Heavyweight Championships by KO'ing Michael Moorer becoming the oldest heavyweight champion in history.

July – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq threatens to end all cooperation with UNSCOM and IAEA if sanctions against the country are not lifted by August 31. Following the defection of his son-in-law, Hussein Kamel al-Majid, Saddam Hussein makes new revelations about the full extent of Iraq's biological and nuclear weapons programs.
May 14 – The Dalai Lama proclaims 6-year-old Gedhun Choekyi Nyima as the 11th reincarnation of the Panchen Lama, but 3 days later the boy is detained by Chinese authorities and not seen again.
TAROM Flight 371 from Bucharest to Brussels crashes shortly after takeoff killing all 60 people on board.
June 13 – French President Jacques Chirac announces the resumption of nuclear tests in French Polynesia.
May 24 – AFC Ajax wins the UEFA Champions League at the Ernst Happel Stadium in Vienna by defeating A.c. Milan 1–0.
March 1 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi forces refuse UNSCOM inspection teams access to five sites designated for inspection. The teams enter the sites only after delays of up to seventeen hours.
September 10 – Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty signed (it will be ratified 180 days after ratification by 44 Annex 2 countries).

The North Cape oil spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat Scandia ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island. The North Cape Barge is pulled along with it and leaks 820,000 gallons of home heating oil.
The MV Bukoba sinks in Tanzanian waters in Lake Victoria, killing nearly 1,000 people in one of Africa's worst maritime disasters.
January 14 – Jorge Sampaio is elected President of Portugal.
June 16 – About 50 people are killed in the Daïat Labguer (M'sila) massacre in Algeria.
March 4 – U.S. President Bill Clinton bans federal funding for any research on human cloning.
October 1 – Luke Woodham walks into Pearl High School in Pearl, Mississippi and opens fire, killing two girls, after killing his mother earlier that morning.
May 10 – The 7.3 Mw Qayen earthquake strikes eastern Iran with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X. At least 1,567 were killed and 2,300 were injured.
Socialist Party-led Centre-left coalition won the second-round in French legislative elections, began with the third Cohabitation (–).
February 26 – Oprah is cleared of slander in an Amarillo court after a highly publicized court battle with Texas beef moguls.
December 29 – The Khmer Rouge's leaders apologize for the post-Vietnam War genocide in Cambodia that killed more than one million people in the 1970s.
August 4 – The Second Congo War begins; 5.4 million people die before it ends in, making it the bloodiest war, to date, since World War II.

September 25 – Benoit Lecomte finishes his 72-day swim across the Atlantic Ocean, but uncertainty over the exact route and distance covered prevent him from being recognized as the first person to swim across the Atlantic.

August 15 – The Troubles: The Omagh bombing is carried out in Northern Ireland by the Real Irish Republican Army as a reaction to the Good Friday Agreement. Shortly after these events, the group will call a ceasefire in response, signaling an end to the 30+ year conflict.
February 7 – Abdullah II inherits the throne of Jordan, following the death of his father King Hussein.
April 21 Explosions were heard in Belgrade, Niš, Novi Sad, and Subotica. Thousands of people were killed.
July 20 Mercury program: Liberty Bell 7 – piloted by Gus Grissom in – is raised from the Atlantic Ocean. Falun Gong is banned in the People's Republic of China under Jiang Zemin.
NATO launches air strikes against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, marking the first time NATO has attacked a sovereign state.
March 15 – The Santer Commission of the EU resigns over allegations of corruption.

August 12 – The Russian submarine Kursk sinks in the Barents Sea during one of the largest Russian naval exercises since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, resulting in the deaths of all 118 men on board.

May 5 After originating in the Philippines, the ILOVEYOU computer virus spreads quickly throughout the world. A rare conjunction of seven celestial bodies (Sun, Moon, planets Mercury–Saturn) occurs during the new moon.
June 4 – The 7.9 Mw Enggano earthquake shakes southwestern Sumatra, killing 103 people and injuring at least 2,174.
Singapore Airlines Flight 006 collides with construction equipment in the Chiang Kai Shek International Airport, resulting in 83 deaths.

July 2 – France defeats Italy 2–1 after extra time in the final of the UEFA Euro Championship in Association football, becoming the first team to win the World Cup and European Championship consecutively.
Bronze Age began in north Ancient China.
Arrival of the ancestors of the Latins in Italy.
: Pharaoh Mentuhotep II, Eleventh dynasty of Egypt dies.
Dawn of the Capacha Culture in modern-day Colima, Mexico.
– : the "Priest-king torso" was sculpted at Mohenjo-Daro, part of the Indus Valley civilization.
Apple Inc. introduces the iPod, a portable media player and multi-purpose mobile device. The company will sell an estimated 450 million iPod products by May.
September 20 – In an address to a joint session of Congress, U.S. President George W.
Indian Parliament attack: Nine people and five terrorists are killed in a terrorist attack in New Delhi, leading to the – India–Pakistan standoff.
October 24 – The Mars Odyssey arrives at Mars.
April 26 Junichiro Koizumi becomes the 86th Prime Minister of Japan. The Parliament of Ukraine votes to dismiss Prime Minister Viktor Yushchenko.
Bahraini general election: Bahrain holds its first Parliamentary elections since.
The State of Bahrain is declared a constitutional monarchy and becomes the Kingdom of Bahrain.
June 12 – The ImClone stock trading case begins when ImClone Systems CEO Samuel D. Waksal is arrested for insider trading.
February 8–24 – The Winter Olympics are held in Salt Lake City, Utah.
October 27 – Brazilian general election: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is elected President of Brazil.
February 9 – The Cricket World Cup begins. It is held in South Africa, Zimbabwe, and Kenya, and it ends on March 23 with Australia defeating India in the final.
March 17 – U.S. President George W.
The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety comes into effect.
March 6 – SCO Group files a lawsuit against IBM as part of an ongoing dispute regarding the use of Unix in the development of Linux.
The Second Liberian Civil War ends after President Charles Taylor resigns and flees the country.
February 1 – Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy : Janet Jackson suffers a "wardrobe malfunction" during a live performance with Justin Timberlake.
November 16 – NASA's hypersonic Scramjet breaks a record by reaching a velocity of about 7,000 mph (Mach 9.6) in an unpiloted experimental flight.
March 29 – Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia are admitted to NATO, the largest expansion of the organization.
April 1 – George W. Bush signs the Unborn Victims of Violence Act into law.
May 19 – The Muskogee, Oklahoma school district announces it will comply with the Department of Justice's order to permit the wearing of hijab by Muslim students.
January 1 – Jeanna Giese from Wisconsin, United States, comes home from the hospital and officially becomes the first person to ever survive rabies without a vaccination.
The International Olympic Committee awards London the right to host the Summer Olympics.
August 31 – The Al-Aimmah bridge disaster in Baghdad, Iraq kills 953 Shia Muslim pilgrims who were celebrating a religious festival.
May 21 - David Foster Wallace delivers his now-famous commencement address, This is Water at Kenyon College in Ohio.
The European Parliament rejects the proposed directive on the patentability of computer-implemented inventions in its second reading.
January 12 – A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 pilgrims.
February 17 – A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines killing an estimated 1,126 people.
NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter enters orbit around Mars.
October 13 – South Korean Ban Ki-moon is elected as the new Secretary-General of the United Nations, succeeding Kofi Annan.
The United States Armed Forces withdraws its forces in Iceland, thereby disbanding the Iceland Defense Force.
November 7 – The Jokela school shooting happened in Finland.
June 24 – American rapper T.I was involved in a physical altercation with Chaka Zulu, the manager of Ludacris, at the Sunset Tower Hotel in West Hollywood, California.
September 13 – The United Nations General Assembly adopts the Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.
May 17 – The Russian Orthodox Church Abroad and the Moscow Patriarchate re-unite after 80 years of schism.
March 1 – The fourth International Polar Year, a $1.73 billion research program to study both the North Pole and South Pole, is launched in Paris.
Eleven mountaineers from international expeditions die on K2, the second-highest mountain on Earth, in the worst single accident in the history of K2 mountaineering.
August 20 – Spanair Flight 5022 crashes at Madrid–Barajas Airport, killing 154 people on board.
May 28 – The Legislature Parliament of Nepal votes overwhelmingly in favor of abolishing the country's 240-year-old monarchy, turning the country into a republic.

September 15 – financial crisis: Stocks fall sharply Monday on a triptych of Wall Street woe: Lehman Brothers' bankruptcy filing, Merrill Lynch's acquisition by Bank of America, and AIG's unprecedented request for short-term financing from the Federal Reserve.
February 17 – Kosovo formally declares independence from Serbia, to a mixed response from the international community.
September 29 – A 8.1 Mw earthquake strikes Samoa, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII (Very strong), leaving at least 192 people dead.
April 1 – Albania and Croatia join NATO.

August 1 – Former President of the Philippines Corazon Aquino dies at the age of 76 of cardiopulmonary arrest after complications of colon cancer. A memorial service and funeral is scheduled for August 5. (Philippine Daily Inquirer).
August 7 – Typhoon Morakot hits Taiwan, killing 673 and stranding more than 1,000 via the worst flooding on the island in half a century.
The Icelandic government and banking system collapse. Prime Minister Geir Haarde immediately resigns.
November 21 – Eurozone countries agree to a rescue package for the Republic of Ireland from the European Financial Stability Facility in response to the country's financial crisis.

October 22 The International Space Station surpasses the record for the longest continuous human occupation of space, having been continuously inhabited since November 2, (3641 days). The Iraq War Documents leak occurs, being deemed the biggest US government leak in history.
January 19 Mahmoud Al-Mabhouh is assassinated in Dubai. North Caucasian Federal District was split from Southern Federal District by decree of Russian president Dmitry Medvedev.

May 12 Following the 6 May United Kingdom general election, the Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties agree to form a coalition government, the UK's first since the Second World War. Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771 crashes at runway at Tripoli International Airport in Libya, killing 103 of the 104 people on board.
October 28 – Dilma Rousseff is elected, becoming the first (and, so far, the only) female president from Brazil.
January 25 – The Egyptian revolution begins.

February 11 – Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak resigns after widespread protests calling for his departure, leaving control of Egypt in the hands of the military, until a general election can be held.
May 24 – The El Reno–Piedmont tornado, an EF5 tornado, strikes El Reno and Piedmont, Oklahoma, killing 9 people and injuring 181.
July 9 – South Sudan secedes from Sudan, per the result of the independence referendum held in January.
Basque separatist militant organisation ETA declares an end to its 43-year campaign of political violence, which has killed over 800 people since.
September 22 – The United Kingdom informs the World Health Organization about a novel coronavirus case originating from Saudi Arabia.

July 4 CERN announces the discovery of a new particle with properties consistent with the Higgs boson after experiments at the Large Hadron Collider. Sport Club Corinthians Paulista wins the Copa Libertadores by beating the Boca Juniors.

February 1 – Egypt's deadliest football incident known as the Port Said Stadium riot is sparked after local Port Said Al Masry fans attack supporters of Cairo-based team Al Ahly SC. The massacre results in 74 deaths: 72 Al Ahly fans, 1 Al Masry fan and 1 police officer.
May 25 – Houla massacre takes place, perpetrated by the Syrian Arab Army, with 108 being killed.
December 8 – The UN Climate Change Conference in Qatar agrees to extend the Kyoto Protocol until.

United States v. Windsor (570 U.S. 744) decided in the Supreme Court of the United States, overturning a key section of the Defense of Marriage Act and hence granting federal recognition to same-sex marriage in the United States.
June 23 – A bus carrying 47 Romanian tourists to Tivat, Montenegro, crashes in the Morača canyon in central Montenegro, killing 19 people and injuring 27.
October 16 – Lao Airlines Flight 301 crashes on approach to Pakse Airport, Laos, killing all 49 people on board.
April 21 – Businessman Horacio Cartes wins the Paraguayan general election against Efraín Alegre.
April 30 – Willem-Alexander is inaugurated as King of the Netherlands following the abdication of Beatrix.
The FIFA World Cup started with hosts Brazil defeating Croatia 3–1.
Thai coup d'état: The Royal Thai Army overthrows the caretaker government of Niwatthamrong Boonsongpaisan after a failure to resolve the political unrest in Thailand.
December 28 – Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501 from Surabaya, Indonesia, to Singapore crashes into the Java Sea just southwest of Borneo, killing all 162 people on board.

May 22 Thai coup d'état: The Royal Thai Army overthrows the caretaker government of Niwatthamrong Boonsongpaisan after a failure to resolve the political unrest in Thailand. A terrorist attack in Ürümqi, China leaves 43 people dead and more than 90 injured.
July 23–August 3 – The Commonwealth Games takes place in Glasgow, Scotland.
June 18 – Pope Francis releases the encyclical letter Laudato si', dated May 24,.
May 29 – In Tonga, the Mata ʻo e Laʻa Solar Facility is officially opened by King Tupou VI.
Iranian nuclear deal: Iran agrees to long-term limits of its nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief.
"Exclusive: Investigators '90 percent sure' bomb downed Russian plane". Reuters.
June 12–28 – The inaugural European Games are held in Baku, Azerbaijan.
June 10 – Christina Grimmie was shot dead while signing autographs and taking pictures with her fans following a concert performance at the Plaza Live in Orlando, Florida.

December 19 Andrei Karlov, the Russian ambassador to Turkey, is assassinated by an off-duty Turkish police officer at an art exhibition in Ankara. Berlin truck attack: A truck is deliberately driven into the Christmas market next to the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church at Breitscheidplatz in Berlin, leaving 12 people dead and 56 others injured.

30 people are killed and 56 injured in terrorist attacks in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, targeting a hotel and a nearby restaurant. A siege occurs and 176 hostages are released afterwards, by government forces.
December 1 – Following a mourning period of seven weeks after the death and funeral of Bhumibol Adulyadej, Vajiralongkorn formally succeeds his late father as the new King of Thailand.
July 14 – Nice truck attack: 86 people are killed and more than 400 others injured in a truck attack in Nice, France, during Bastille Day celebrations.
June 22 – The African and Caribbean War Memorial unveiled in Brixton, London.
The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons is voted for by 122 states.
September 3 – North Korea conducts its sixth and most powerful nuclear test.

July 7 The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons is voted for by 122 states. ISIL affiliated insurgents attacked an Egyptian military checkpoint in Northern Sinai's Rafah which resulted in the deaths of 26 Egyptian personnel including colonel Ahmed Mansi and 44 other insurgents.
Mauritania holds a constitutional referendum for approval of proposed amendments to the constitution.

October 20 700,000 people march through central London demanding a second referendum on the final Brexit deal. The event is the second most attended protest of the in the United Kingdom after the "Stop the War" anti-Iraq War march in.
January 12–13 – The first round of voting in the Czech presidential election is held.
A shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida is one of the deadliest school massacres with 17 fatalities and 17 injuries.

May 9 – The opposition-led Pakatan Harapan coalition, led by former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, secures a parliamentary majority in the Malaysian Parliament as the result of the Malaysian general election, ending the 61-year rule of the Barisan Nasional coalition since independence in.
October 1 – The International Court of Justice rules that Chile is not obliged to negotiate access to the Pacific Ocean with Bolivia.
Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi asks the House Judiciary Committee to begin drafting the articles of impeachment against U.S.
December 5 The Burundi landslide is reported to have caused at least 26 deaths. Speaker of the U.S.
November 23 – The last known Sumatran rhinoceros in Malaysia dies.
Yclone Bulbul kills seven in West Bengal, India and seven in Bangladesh. 2,000,000 people are evacuated.
The Nanfang'ao Bridge, the only steel single-arch bridge in Taiwan, collapses, killing six people and injuring more than twenty others.

October 31 – Typhoon Goni makes landfall in the Philippines, becoming the strongest landfalling tropical cyclone in history, displacing hundreds of thousands of people and killing dozens of people in the region.
The Croatian parliamentary election is held to elect all 151 members of the Croatian Parliament.
OVID-19 pandemic: The number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 passes 45 million worldwide.
Bahrain and Israel agree to normalise relations, marking the fourth Israel–Arab peace deal.

August 9 – A presidential election in Belarus which led to incumbent Alexander Lukashenko's reelection sparks protests throughout the country after major opposition candidate Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya rejected the results. Seven days later, the largest political march in Belarusian history takes place, with an estimated 300,000 people in Minsk and 200,000 in other Belarusian cities and towns.
May 19 – The European Parliament unanimously adopted a resolution calling for the formal suspension of accession negotiations between the European Union and Turkey.
February 20 – –21 H5N8 outbreak: 7 people test positive for H5N8 bird flu at a poultry farm in southern Russia, becoming the first known human cases.
Bulgaria holds a parliamentary election, with the party There Is Such a People leading.
Max Verstappen won his first Formula One World Championship and the first for a Dutch driver, driving for Red Bull Racing at the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix.
January 10 – Kim Jong Un is elected as the General Secretary of the ruling Workers' Party of Korea, inheriting the title from his father Kim Jong Il, who died in.

August 12 – Indian-born British-American novelist Salman Rushdie is stabbed multiple times as he is about to give a public lecture at the Chautauqua Institution in Chautauqua, New York, United States.
The Nord Stream pipeline sabotage occurs by an unknown perpetrator off the coast of Bornholm, Denmark with explosions on two pipelines leaving them inoperable.

January 13 – Bikaner-Guwahati Express derailment: The Bikaner-Guwahati Express train derailed in Maynaguri. 9 people were killed and 50 people were injured. This was the first major train accident of.

December 14 - Irish peacekeeper Private Seán Rooney is killed in Lebanon during an attack by a mob that surrounded his convoy. He is the first Irish peacekeeper killed in action in Lebanon in twenty years.

January 4 – The five permanent members of the UN Security Council—China, France, Russia, the United Kingdom and the United States—issue a rare joint statement affirming that "a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.".
August 20 – Guatemalan presidential election: After two rounds of voting, Bernardo Arévalo of Semilla is elected with 58% of the vote.

Gaza war: Hamas launches an incursion into southern Israel from the Gaza Strip, killing more than 1,100 Israelis and taking about 240 hostages, prompting a military response from the Israel Defense Forces. Israel launches numerous air strikes on Lebanon after rockets are fired by Hezbollah and further attempts are made to penetrate Israel.
January 27–28 – The second round of the Czech presidential election is held, with Petr Pavel declared winner.

Following the Brazilian general election and the inauguration of Lula da Silva as president of Brazil, supporters of former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro storm the Brazilian National Congress, the Supreme Federal Court and the Presidential Palace of Planalto.
February 21 – Vladimir Putin announces that Russia is suspending its participation in New START, a nuclear arms reduction treaty with the US.
San Marino general election: The Democracy and Freedom alliance, headed by the PDCS, wins a plurality in the Grand and General Council.
Julian Assange was freed from prison on June 242024 Hajj disaster: More than 1,300 people are reported to have died due to extreme heat during the annual Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.

December 12 – Indian chess prodigy Gukesh Dommaraju defeats former world champion Ding Liren in the World Chess Championship, breaking the previous age record of 22 set by Garry Kasparov by becoming champion at 18 years, 195 days old.
November 5 United States presidential election: Former U.S. President Donald Trump defeats incumbent Vice President Kamala Harris to win a second nonconsecutive term.
Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates become BRICS members.

April 26 The funeral of Pope Francis is attended by delegations from 164 countries, including 82 leaders, and 250,000 members of the public. An explosion in the Port of Shahid Rajaee, Bandar Abbas, Iran, kills at least 70 people and injures more than 1,000.
April 22 – Militants affiliated with The Resistance Front open fire on a group of tourists at the Baisaran Valley in Jammu and Kashmir, India, killing 26 and injuring at least 20.

January 1 Poland takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, after the Hungarian presidency. Bulgaria and Romania complete the process of joining the Schengen Area, lifting land border controls.
November 27–30 – An ecumenical meeting of the Eastern Orthodox Church and Catholic Church at Nicaea is held to mark the 1,700th anniversary of the First Council of Nicaea.
Norwegian parliamentary election: Incumbent Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre's coalition retains their majority.
August 30 – The Estonian presidential election is scheduled to be held.
May – The Lebanese general election is scheduled to be held.
January 25 – The –26 Myanmar general election is scheduled to be held.
Equatorial Guinea moves its capital from Malabo to Ciudad de la Paz.
The Slovenian parliamentary election is scheduled to be held.

Abandonment of the Mature Harappan settlement at Kalibangan in India due to the drying-up of the Ghaggar River.
Supposed reign of the semi-legendary Sumerian king Gilgamesh.

A bronze bar produced in Nippur defines the cubit.

Ur becomes one of the richest cities in Sumer.
: Ancient Egypt: Pharaoh Qa'a died. End of First Dynasty, start of Second Dynasty.

: Egyptian 2nd Dynasty Prince Raneb born around this year in history.
: There is an intense phase of burial at Duma na nGiall on the Hill of Tara, the ancient seat of the High King of Ireland.
: Stonehenge begins to be built. In its first version, it consists of a circular ditch and bank, with 56 wooden posts.
: Camels are domesticated in Egypt.
: Troy is founded on this date (assuming the interpretation of Manfred Korfmann is followed).

: Narmer unifies Upper and Lower Egypt into one country; he rules this new country from Memphis.

Major climate shift possibly due to shift in solar activity. Glaciers expand, covering plants; atmospheric temperatures fall.
Indus Valley civilisation (also known as Harappan civilization) begins in Harappa.

-3000 : Evidence of proto-Thracians or proto-Dacians in the prehistoric period; Proto-Dacian or proto-Thracian people developed from a mixture of indigenous peoples and Indo-Europeans from the time of Proto-Indo-European expansion in the Early Bronze Age.
Ancient Egypt begins using clay, bone and ivory tags to label boxes, possibly an example of proto-writing.

: The Sumerians develop a logographic script, cuneiform.
